title: its never late next two
story: Its never too late - the next two weeks in Glasgow could stop the worst happeningFormer prime minister Gordon Brown says the next fortnight in Glasgow for the COP summit could stop the worst happening to the world - but leaders must be boldGordon Brown has warned the world its not too late to avert the worst of climate change Image: Getty ImagesopinionByGordon Brown:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsIt is never too late to do the right thing. And while the disastrous effects of climate change are already causing havoc in countries across the world, there is still time to stop the worst from happening. It is not too much of over-statement to say that the next two weeks in Glasgow will decide this one way or the other. The summit will confirm plenty of good work that is already happening. The worldwide phasing out of coal will be announced this week – to be delivered in the s. As will the switch to electric cars and away from diesel and petrol engines. And the planting of billions more trees to soak up carbon.What do you think of this  Join the debate in our comments But fundamentally, the dference between progress and catastrophe will hang on two make or break decisions. Firstly, just how big each country’s carbon reductions will be during the s. And secondly, just how much financial help rich countries will give poor countries to cut out carbon At the centre of the Paris accords of  was an agreement that countries would ratchet up their carbon reduction ambitions at COP . But now with China likely to refuse to bring its ‘cap’ forward or advance its ‘peak’ level forward from , the best achievable outcome is to agree to ‘kick the cap down the road’.  So our best hope here is not an agreement on new targets but that Glasgow lays the ground for a new target-setting conference in . But any commitments by low and middle income countries to transition to net zero emissions cannot and will not be forthcoming without a dramatic increase in global climate finance. And unless the richest countries make a bolder financial offer to coastal states and developing countries hardest hit by climate induced emergencies, COP  cannot succeed. A burden sharing agreement where rich countries agreed to pay based on their wealth and their culpability for historic emissions would have made sense but instead countries simply offer what they like. As conference chair Britain should be taking the lead, but while Britain has doubled its developing countries funding to £ .bn a year, it has bent the rules - and now seeks to do what no other country has attempted to count loans transferred from the IMF to the UK and the UK back to the IMF as overseas development assistance. But If we are to convince laggards - Australia , Canada, Japan, Italy - to do more or to convince America -whose bn commitment remains too small- to make good their shortfall in financial commitments , then we .Britian, must do better. To reach bn, restore trust and bring developing countries on board we need a new initiative to break the deadlock and I look to John Kerry the US negotiator, President Biden and Mr Sharma to break the deadlock. We must not give up but continue to fight for climate justice - and a world where economic progress and social justice go hand in hand with a sustainable environment. I take heart from the millions of our fellow citizen especially a new generation of young people now aware of t the costs of pollution to their quality of le. Paris, Kyoto and Rio are already on the history books of a cities linked to environmental breakthroughs. I want Glasgow to take its place alongside them as a city associated with real and lasting change on the climate but it will require our political leaders to step up from today and show leadership and imagination. title: rishi sunaks budget no inspiration
story: Rishi Sunaks Budget had no inspiration, no insight, and no hope for the futureBridget Phillipson, Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, on what Rishi Sunaks bankers budget should have contained - and what Labour would do dferentlyBridget Phillipson writes in the Mirror tonight Image: Getty ImagesopinionByBridget Phillipson, Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWednesdayaposs Budget was not what Britain needed. There was no plan to tackle the growing cost of living crisis. No plan to reduce the tax burden on working people and small businesses. No plan to grow our economy in the years ahead or to create the high-wage high skilled jobs of the future. No plan to deal with the huge challenge of climate change for the years ahead. A Labour budget would have been very dferent, because Labour wants a brighter and better future for our country. We’d have invested in dealing with the challenge of climate change and fitting our country for the future - starting with proper insulation for millions of homes to reduce emissions and drive down soaring heating bills.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section We’d have changed the way the government does business to ensure we buy, make, and sell more in Britain, supporting manufacturers and our amazing small businesses. Growing our economy is the best route to better services and a better future for everyone. It means more jobs and higher tax revenues to invest in our services. Instead, after a decade of weak growth, Wednesday’s budget saw taxation go up to the highest level for seventy years. Working people are paying an ever higher price for eleven years of Tory economic failure. We’d have invested in the future of our public services, especially for children, as we recover from the pandemic, with a properly funded education catch-up plan so every child has the chance to succeed. We only get one chance as a country to get these calls right, and the Tories are getting it wrong. We’d have cancelled the Prime Minister’s new yacht, and spent the money on policing hubs and more special constables.  And we’d have reformed our tax system, as Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves set out at conference. We’d make it fair, so those with the broadest shoulders make the bigger contribution. We’d bring it up to date, so high street family firms face a level playing field with tech giants like Amazon. We’d make it more efficient too, by removing unfair tax breaks, like the one that benefits private schools - and spend that money on giving every child a better start. What we needed was a Budget for our future, for growth, and for our public services. The Tories failed again to deliver what we need. Labour would be building a brighter and better future. title: sunaks budget more proof hes
story: Sunaks budget more proof hes out of touch but Labour would put working people firstShadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves on how Boris Johnsons government and Rishi Sunaks budget leave working people paying more for less for three reasons - economic mismanagement, an unfair tax system and wasteful spendingShadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves responds to the Budget opinionByRachel Reeves:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWe needed a Budget for a secure economy. Instead, we got a Chancellor disconnected from the reality of a growing cost of living crisis. As energy bills soar, the Chancellor piled the biggest tax burden in peacetime on working people. As businesses on our high streets are held back by outdated business rates, the Chancellor gave bankers a tax cut. A decade of sluggish growth. Public services cut to the bone. Billions of pounds of taxpayer money wasted. But still, no plan to boost our economy. The Government will always blame others for its failures. But the reality is that working people are paying more for less for three simple reasons. Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  Economic mismanagement. An unfair tax system. And wasteful spending. Our country deserves better. But they’ll never get it under a Chancellor who gives with one hand, but takes so much more with the other. People are getting wise to this. Every month they feel the pinch. They are tired of the smoke and mirrors, of the bluster, of the  dawns, of the promises of jam tomorrow. Use our autumn Budget tax calculator to see how it will impact your money - The solution starts with growth. Labour would put working people first. The Government is caught in a bind of its own making. Low growth leads to less money for public services, unless taxes rise. Labour would use the power of government and business to create the next generation of quality jobs right here, in Britain. We’d tax fairly, spend wisely and after a decade of faltering growth, we’d get Britain’s economy firing on all cylinders. That is what a Labour budget would have done today. title: water firms pumping sewage sea
story: Water firms pumping sewage into the sea - and the Government voted for it to carry onNow weve left the EU, firms are free from outside interference and able to dispose of sewage by simply slinging it in the sea, in shades of Tudor England, argues Mark SteelMark Steel thinks this wouldnt have happened before Brexit Image: Cambridge NewsopinionByMark Steel:,  Oct British business is free of interference at last. For so long our companies were held back by petty regulations, often from Europe, but now that’s in the past and they’re allowed to pour human sewage into the sea. Instead of going through the palaver of disposing of our waste in complicated ways, it was revealed this week that water companies have been flinging it into the seaside. And the government voted to let them carry on! So our children can enjoy watching pretty shapes float about while they’re paddling. In Tudor times, we were encouraged to chuck our waste into the street. But do-gooding boffins brought in one rule after another, and before long we weren’t even allowed to poke our bums out of our own windows and defecate on to the pavement!  That was the trouble with the th century, it was full of health and safety gone mad. But now the government has voted to allow our water companies to pump our great British turds into the water to boost our seaside towns. Imagine the joy as parents call out to their kids: “Grab your bucket and spade, we’re going to Scarborough to make some poo castles.” The water companies wouldn’t have been allowed to act like thiswe were still tied to the EU. In , Michael Gove promised a “Green Brexit”, and he’s been true to his word, because lots of the jolly sewage must be a very deep shade of green. Ministers reassured us that an amendment to the law will “reverse adverse impacts”, but let’s hope they can keep all the positive impacts of human ­effluence plopping in front of us while we’re swimming. Maybe one measure they could look at is thatour beaches are to become toilets, we should ide them into gents and ladies beaches, with Torquay and Bournemouth being mixed so as not to discriminate against the trans community. I expect the water companies will say they’ve taken responsibility for the smell by chucking a couple of little blue things you get in public urinals into the North Sea. That should clear it up. Want the big political stories sent straight to your inbox for the Mirror Politics newsletter here The reason this is all possible is the priority of the water companies is not the outdated miserable business of providing water. Instead, they concentrate on the more exciting task of providing a profit for their shareholders. Since they were privatised, they’ve paid out £billion in profits, so with all that to think about, you can’t blame them for not having the time to stop poo bouncing into the sea. So we should be thrilled our water is in such safe hands. Because from the earliest of times, the planet has depended on one commodity above all , which is shareholders’ idends. And these companies are working selflessly, day and night, to keep this precious resource fresh and plentul. Water, on the other hand, doesn’t matter very much, so we might as well stick a million tons of poo into it and sling it into the sea. title: army unit most casualties iraq
story: Exclusive: Army unit with most casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan suffers  suicides in four yearsThe Rles saw  soldiers killed in action in both the Iraq and Afghnistan wars and in the past four years has seen the Armys worst suicide rate as at least  members of the infantry regiment took their own livesCaptain Gary Case is believed to have taken his own le just weeks after he received an MBE from the QueenBySean Rayment:,  Oct | commentsThe regiment which suffered the most casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan also has the Army’s worst suicide rate. Sixty-six soldiers from The Rles were killed in action in both wars while a further  were wounded, say official figures. And in the past four years at least  members of the infantry regiment have taken their own lives, according to Veterans United Against Suicide. One, Captain Gary Case, , is believed to have taken his own le in  just weeks after he received an MBE from the Queen. Warrant Officer Jim Wilde, one of the founders of VUAS, said: “The data recorded over the last four years reveals categorically that The Rles have a suicide rate far higher than any other unit. Have your say on this story in the comment section This is a direct consequence of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. “The Ministry of Defence should have done more to help veterans and serving members of the regiment.” General Sir Patrick Sanders, , one of the most senior commanders in the Army and a former Rles officer, revealed earlier this year that he had contemplated suicide after a violent tour and urged soldiers and veterans to get help.  He said: “I found myself obsessing about experiences, dwelling on photographs, video clips, letters, replaying in my mind what happened in a dark and obsessive way. “These thoughts took me to a dark place. When I caught myself at two in the morning with a bottle of wine or whisky next to me, I realised that I needed help.” The MoD said a “wealth of mental health and support” was available, while work is ongoing to gather data on trends. It added: “This will provide evidence to support further changes to prevention and intervention activity and the provision of post-event support.” Comment MORE ON British ArmyMinistry of DefenceJim WildeSoldiersArmed forcesMental healthIraqSunday PeopleSuicide" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news balding-woman-left-tears-after-"Balding pensioner gets fresh new look after hair replacementBySimon GreenVideo News Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA woman whose hair loss had eroded her self esteem and caused her to avoid photos and mirrors for two decades was reduced to tears after having her lost locks replaced. Brenda Vickers, , decided to take action to fix her receding hairline and dwindling confidence, so visited hair replacement firm Novo Cabelo to get her mojo back. In a video shared on TikTok, Novo Cabelo owner Rob wood can be seen attaching a £ “hair system”, which is made with real hairs. When blindfolded Brenda sees the finished work she can’t help but tear up and ask: “Have I got all this hair ” More than , people have watched the footage, with many also finding it emotional and claiming her new appearance has made her look  years younger. Brenda, who suffers from coeliac, said the transformation would boost her confidence and enable her to visit the shops more often. The pensioner, from Walkergate, Newcastle upon Tyne, said: It feels good that I donapost have to be self-conscious when I go out. I donapost have to feel embarrassed anymore and think aposI donapost want to look at myselfapos.  Itaposs changed everything. Iaposll go out more now because I can feel confident and thataposs an unbelievable feeling. Everybody who Iaposve spoken to has been so complimentary and kind.“My head should be massive,” she told the Daily Star.People have been saying I look  years younger, but Iaposve still got the brain of a -year-old. My body is old but my hair is young. Iaposve not seen myself look like this for so long.” Brenda’s husband Brian, , was equally gobsmacked at the finished result of the hair system. Itaposs like being married to someone  years younger. Itaposs a good job Iaposve still got plenty of hair as well. [The transformation] is beautul, so Iaposm so pleased for her. Itaposs spot on. You couldnapost ask for anything better.  I really got a shock when I first saw her. I found her very attractive. Sheaposs not a bad looker, you know  The former admin worker believes her hair loss is due to the immune system disorder celiac, which she was diagnosed with in  but claims sheaposs been suffering from for  years. To achieve the new look, a stretchy ‘poly skin’ membrane was attached to her head with double-sided adhesive tape made especially for skin. It was fitted with existing hair and will last around six months. title: brave harmonie 7 sums up
story: Brave Harmonie, , sums up the Pride of Britain awards with her extraordinary courageHarmonie-Rose Allen shows all the courage and superhuman achievements synonymousLittle Harmonies bravery sums up the Pride of Britain awards with her courage Image: Bath Chronicle   SWNSopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Oct | commentsFor more than two decades the Mirror’s Pride of Britain has heralded the extraordinary courage and superhuman achievements of ordinary people. People such as seven-year-old Harmonie-Rose Allen. Despite losing her arms and legs to meningitis she’s raised £, for charity by completing feats doctors said were impossible. People such as Rob Allen. He founded Sands United – a network of football teams where men can grieve together over children they have lost. People such as Gee Walker. She forgave her son’s killers and dedicated herself to promoting racial harmony. And people such as those on the Oxford-AstraZeneca team whose vaccine made this year’s Pride of Britain so dferent from the last.  Without them there would be no live audience to join in the tears and laughter or marvel at human stories, both heartwarming and heartbreaking. Their jab helped make near-normal le possible. The guest list for the evening is a Who’s Who of the famous – from Hollywood’s Sharon Stone to Stephen Fry, from TV’s Simon Cowell to Olympian Mo Farah. But they are there only as supporting actors for a cast of real people stepping into the limelight to showcase the very best of Britain. Our nation has suffered hugely over the last  months of the pandemic. But when the awards are televised on Thursday, everyone will have the chance to honour those who have endured much and achieved more than most of us do in a letime. It is a reminder that no matter how tough the challenges, the human spirit can find reserves of strength to overcome them. A reminder that after months of lockdown there is much out there to celebrate. And a reminder of the people of Britain of whom we can be most proud. No COPout Boris Johnson is usually Mr Optimism. So when he puts success at the COP climate change summit at little better than -, failure is clearly on the cards. The Prime Minister admits that the representatives of  nations are unlikely to reach agreement on how to keep global warming down to .C above pre-industrial levels. And key players President Xi of China and President Putin of Russia cannot even be bothering to turn up – although Xi is to address the summit by video link.  Yet their co-operation is neededclimate change is not to devastate the planet. So there is a danger that the crucial inter-national conference in Glasgow to curb the world’s hot air will end up with politicians just spouting it. But just because the , delegates are not going to hit their goal it does not mean they should not have a shot at the net. Firm commitments from world leaders who are there will take us a few more steps along the road to making our planet a safer place. And help pave the way for lasting success at the next summit. news uk-news british-skipper-faces-trial-huge-"France seizes British boat amidst Brexit fishing rowByAndy LinesChief reporterPeter Allen:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The skipper of a British trawler seized by the French during an escalating row over fishing licences is to go on criminal trial and faces a fine equivalent to more than £,.Prosecutors in Le Havre on Friday confirmed that the captain of the Cornelis Gert Jan will appear before judges on August .He has been charged with ‘acts of unauthorised sea fishing in French maritime salt waters by a third party vessel to the European Union ’. It comes after Catherine Colonna, France’s ambassador to the UK, was summoned to the Foreign Office in London to explain ‘disappointing and disproportionate’ threats of retaliation by Paris over what it claims is a lack of licences for French boats to fish in UK waters.The skipper of the Cornelis, who had not been publicly identied, is specically accused of having fished , kg of scallops in the French exclusive economic zone without holding a valid licence.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  He now faces a fine of €,as well as administrative sanctions, said le Havre deputy prosecutor Cyrille Fournier. Mr Fournier said: The captain of the Cornelis Gert Jan was given a summons by maritime police to appear at the hearing of the Criminal Court of Le Havre on August , . The prosecutor added: After verication, the captain of the vessel did not have the authorisation required to fish in the French exclusive economic zone.This was despite claims by the owners of the Cornelis that the boat had been fishing legally when it was detained on Wednesday night.Andrew Brown, director of Scottish firm MacDuff Shellfish, said she was being used as a apospawnapos by angry French ministers. Mr Brown said before news of the court action: MacDuffaposs fishing activity is entirely legal. We are looking to the UK government to defend the rights of the UK fishing fleet and ensure that the fishing rights provided under the Brexit fishing agreement are fully respected by the EU.On Friday morning, the Cornelis was still moored in Le Havre - still banned from leaving the port. The French ambassador has been summoned the Foreign Office in London later today to explain why the boat was detained. The crew of the Cornelis Gert Jan are still onboard as the legal battle rumbles on. It is moored up in a quiet area of the harbour with a sign saying “no unauthorised entry” on the gangplank. Boat owner Andrew Brown insisted they had all the right paperwork and the vessel should be allowed to leave as soon as possible. The boat had headed out from Shoreham, Sussex, early on Tuesday morning, and had expected to spend five days catching scallops in the English Channel.  Her seizure is the latest move by France in an ongoing row with the UK over who has rights to fishing grounds in the Channel now Britain has left the EU. The Cornelis’s haul has been thrown back overboard by the French, while her skipper spoke to an examining magistrate with the help of a French lawyer. Gendarmes on board the Athos – the police boat named after one of the Three Musketeers which detained the Cornelis– also fined a second, unidentied British boat on Wednesday. Her skipper was dealt with for initially refusing police permission to board, but then left toto the UK. Clement Beaune, Franceaposs Europe minister, has said we need to speak the language of force to Britain because it is the only thing this government understands. He was immediately accused of sabre rattling by British critics, as was Annick Girardin, the Maritime Minister in Paris, who said: It’s not war, but it is a fight. Referencing Brexit, Ms Girardin said: We are going to ask the European Commission to tell the United Kingdom that it is not respecting its agreement and therefore that retaliatory measures can be put in place. Before Brexit, French fishermen had free rights to fish in UK waters under EU law and only had to apply to their own government for a licence. But earlier this year the new Brexit Agreement came into force, meaning French fishermen now need to apply to the UK for a licence. All vessels that fished in UK waters aposfor at least four years between  and apos should be granted the same level of access until at least , when it will be up to the UK and France to negotiate new deals. The UK is asking French boats to provide tracking and fishing quota data for those years to qualy for a permit. The French have protested, saying smaller vessels under m do not collect this data and are being unfairly punished. The Brexit Agreement makes no mention of such data, they argue. British environment minister George Eustice told Parliament the seizure of the boat is being aposurgentlyapos looked into, but ruled out any apostit for tatapos retaliation. UK vessels with their licence to fish in EU waters should be allowed to do so uninterrupted, he said. news uk-news british-skipper-trawler-trapped-france-"Skipper of trapped trawler doesnt know when crew can go homeByAndy LinesChief reporter:,  Oct  The skipper of the trawler at the centre of the British fishing row tonight spoke to the Mirror from his boat to say he has no idea when he will be going home.He said the boat was still banned from leaving Le Havre harbour. Askedhis crew were now allowed off to exercise and visit local shops he said: “as far as I know.” He undid a window on the trawler to speak following a y meeting with his legal team onshore. He said he expected to be in France a “while. Once back onboard he briefed some of his crew. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterIt was reported on Friday that the skipper, whose boat was seized by the French during an escalating row over fishing licences, will go on criminal trial and faces a fine equivalent to more than £,.Prosecutors in Le Havre on Friday confirmed that the captain of the Cornelis Gert Jan will appear before judges on August .He has been charged with ‘acts of unauthorised sea fishing in French maritime salt waters by a third party vessel to the European Union ’. It comes after Catherine Colonna, France’s ambassador to the UK, was summoned to the Foreign Office in London to explain ‘disappointing and disproportionate’ threats of retaliation by Paris over what it claims is a lack of licences for French boats to fish in UK waters.The skipper of the Cornelis is specically accused of having fished , kg of scallops in the French exclusive economic zone without holding a valid licence. Yesterday French President Emmanuel Macron escalated the post-Brexit row raging between Paris and London when he questioned Britainaposs credibility and accused it of wanting to change parts of a treaty signed just last year over fishing rights and other topics. Speaking to the Financial Times, Macron said other nations were watching closely as Britain clashed with France and the broader European Union following its departure from the bloc.  Britain, looking to strike new trade deals after leaving the EU, had threatened to open trade dispute proceedings against FranceParis imposed sanctions on London. Such a step could seriously disrupt trade between the neighbours. Make no mistake, it is not just for the Europeans but all of their partners, Macron said. Because when you spend years negotiating a treaty and then a few months later you do the opposite of what was decided on the aspects that suit you the least, it is not a big sign of your credibility. Macron and Prime Minister Boris Johnson are due to meet briefly this weekend at the G meeting in Rome, offering a chance to ease tensions. On the flight from London, Johnson told reporters France was one of our best, oldest, closest allies, friends and partners, and that he would make that clear to Macron when they met.  Johnson added that he was puzzled by the fishing dispute and feared Paris may have breached terms of the Brexit trade deal. Obviously weaposre going to take the appropriate action, he added. Britainaposs departure from the EU last year deepened strains in its relations with France, and negotiations on fishing rights proved long and dficult even before it left the bloc. France says Britain has refused to grant its fishermen the full number of licences to operate in British waters that France says is warranted. Britain says it is issuing licences to vessels that can prove they have previously fished in UK waters. The Cornelis Gert Jan was escorted to the northern French port of Le Havre overnight on Wednesday after French officials said its crew failed to prove it was allowed to fish in French waters. British officials said it had the correct documentation. Angered by the incident, and by the threat of sanctions, British Environment Secretary George Eustice said on Friday: Two can play at that game. title: brit preppers always ready armageddon
story: Exclusive: Brit preppers always ready for Armageddon were dismissed as paranoid - then Covid hitThe US survival trend of prepping is taking off in the UK and, when the Covid- pandemic hit, Dr Sarita Robinson didn’t need to buy food for three months - because shes always ready for armageddonDr Sarita Robinson with her emergency supplies Image: David NelsonByDan Hall:,  Oct | commentsDeadly pandemics, fuel ­shortages and the breakdown of vital supply chains were once the stuff of ­disaster movies.But, while we’re getting used to panic-buying toilet rolls and petrol after Covid and Brexit, some savvy Brits were ready years before.Preppers – those who “prepare” for natural disasters and other emergencies by learning survival skills and stocking up on food and equipment – have long been dismissed as paranoid extremists.For most, it conjures up images of isolated, heavily armed groups such as the Fortitude Ranch, deep in the woods of West Virginia, US, ready to retreat to their bunker and fend off all those who come near. But the movement – in a much more modest form – has been quietly growing in the UK too.What do you think of the apospreppersapos  Have your say in the comment section  Survival psychologist Dr Sarita Robinson, , began prepping after moving from Lancashire to Calornia’s San Andreas fault earthquake zone in the early s to work on her PhD. She says: “I was writing about earthquake survivors and preppers. What became clear was that those who prepped were better at surviving. “I realised I was living in quite a hazardous area and maybe I should have a quake survival kit.”  The habit stayed with her. Now teaching at the University of Central Lancashire in Preston, she still keeps a “go bag” in her car, with things such as waterproof clothes and first aid equipment. Her readiness served her well when Covid hit. Dr Robinson says: “I was talking to my boss as we were abandoning the university. “He said to me, ‘Sarita, we used to laugh at you – but we’re not laughing now…’”  As panic-buying kicked in, Dr Robinson did not need to buy food for three months, relying instead on stores she already had. She adds: “For a generation, we’ve had an absolute guarantee basic services will continue regardless. There’s this slow, dawning realisation that things can go wrong really quickly. “People were saying, ‘So it was you who was buying it all’, and I’d go, ‘No, I bought it a year ago when there wasn’t a problem!’”  Prepper Justin Jones saw the panic-buying as an opportunity to restart the survival business he had closed in . Justin, , says: “What sparked me off was the toilet paper fights in Tesco. Then they started the food rationing, where you could only have three packets of pasta per customer.” When he began selling survival gear such as crossbows and water filters through his UK Prepping Shop  months ago, orders flooded in – and have risen ten-fold since. One of his best-sellers is a six-month food kit costing £..  He says: “Years ago people laughed at preppers in the UK. Now they’re saying, ‘Actually, let’s just get a bit in case’, you know ” Lincoln Miles, , has seen a similar surge at his Newquay-based Preppers Shop UK in Cornwall. He has gone from having one member of staff to  to help him keep up with demand for military-grade gas masks and pre-packed “bug out bags” stocked with knives, mess tins and hammocks. Miles says: “If someone had a year’s worth of food, you’d think, ‘What a nutter’. That was always the perception, that preppers were on the outskirts of normality. That has definitely changed. I think people realise everyone’s got a bit ofprepper in them.”Michael ‘Roach’ Sanderson, , believes the idea behind prepping has been misunderstood. In  years in the military and  as a paramedic, he has seen how disasters can happen to anyone at any time. He says: “People talk about ­armageddon and the end of the world and make preppers sound like some ­religious cult. It’s not like that. Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters“They’re regular people with an eye and ear on what’s going on.” Michael’s YouTube channel, called “armouredcockroach”, covers skills such as making a splint for a broken bone or cooking a hot meal with no gas or ­electricity. On it he also shows off his array of gear – including his “bug out vehicle” – a Land Rover that contains everything he would need to survive in the wilderness.  When the pandemic first hit, Michael, his we and two children lived off a three-month supply of dehydrated food. He says: “We locked the door on the world because we had everything we needed. That’s it.” Dr Michael Mills, a lecturer in ­criminology at the University of Kent, has been studying prepping for the past decade. He says: “There’s always been a small subculture in the UK, but it started to gain popularity around the time of Brexit. “While in the US it’s mainly right-wing, British prepping is grounded more in liberal or centrist politics.”Dr Mills cites one Facebook group with , members, but says most people are “uncomfortable” about the idea of preppers.He adds: “We think like them a little, but want to keep them at arm’s . Otherwise, it means facing up to problems we’d rather not admit are as serious as they might seem.” essential items to keep in your stock- Tips from Sharyn McInally-Johnston from Prepper’s Paradise survival shop . First Aid Kit: A good stock of your regular medications, plus off-the-shelf staples such as paracetamol, ibuprofen, aspirin, antihistamines and dehydration powders, is a good start.. Torch: In a storm or disaster, power cuts are common and even familiar spaces can become dangerous.. Water: It’s essential to have a water carrier that can hold enough for your household to cover drinking, cooking, washing and cleaning.. Long-Le Food: Options include regular tinned and cupboard food, dehydrated or freeze-dried.. Off-Grid charger or power bank: Power banks, solar charges and car chargers are perfect to keep your smartphone running.Comment MORE ON EnergyCoronavirusCoronavirus lockdownPeopleSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: cancel culture modern witch hunting
story: Cancel culture is modern witch hunting - just ask JK Rowling and Prof Kathleen StockLets ditch the witch hunts this Halloween, writes Rachael Bletchly, as worldwide efforts to get justice for women condemned and murdered for impossible witchcraft crimes in the past helps us recognise injustice today In this file photo taken on February ,  British author J. K. Rowling poses upon arrival at the BAFTA British Academy Film Awards at the Royal Albert Hall in London on February , " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _FILES-BRITAIN-GENDER-AWARD-LITERATURE-PEOPLE-ROWLING.jpg" width"" "" Is JK Rowling the victim of a modern-day witch hunt  Image: AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Oct | commentsMy Halloween costume of choice was always a witch. Pointy hat, long black cloak and a broomstick with a cuddly black cat glued to it. Easy. Because everyone knows what a real witch looks like, don’t they  They glared at us from the pages of childhood fairy stories, screeched their spells around bubbling cauldrons on dramatic blasted heaths and cackled their way through hundreds of films and TV series. Those are the images that spring to mind when someone says “witch”. Not the tens of thousands of innocent women murdered during three centuries of global hysteria from the s to s. Wives and mothers drowned or burned at the stake simply because a neighbour with a grudge said he’d seen them flying a broomstick.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Healers, herbalists and midwives, ­condemned for their “dark arts” or the ale brewers who wore pointed hats to signy their trade and kept cats to chase mice away. Victims like Lilias Addie from Fe, Scotland, a woman in her s who was over ft tall with unusual physical ­features…and thus blamed for a spate of illness in her village in . She was imprisoned, tortured, deprived of sleep and interrogated, and then after a month she confessed to fornicating with the devil. Mercully, perhaps, Lilias died in prison before she could be burned alive.  Her body was buried under a half-ton stone slab on the sea shore to prevent the devil bringing her back to le. Grave robbers dug her up in  and her bones were exhibited before dis­ap­pearing. But in  her face was digitally reconstructedfrom photographs taken of the remains – ­revealing a sad, gentle, intelligent woman robbed of her dignity by superstition, prejudice and fear. Lilias is now the focus of a campaign in Scotland to win pardons for the ­estimated , Scots executed under the Witchcraft Act of . It is part of a wider worldwide effort to get justice for ALL women condemned and murdered for impossible witchcraft “crimes”. Because facing up to past injustice helps us recognise injustice today. And witch-hunting is an all-too modern phenomenon…we just call it “cancel culture” now. Ask wizard creator, JK Rowling, branded “a vile, rotten, raggedy old hag” for her views on sex and gender. Or philosophy Professor Kathleen Stock, bullied and harassed out of her university job for daring to have her own opinions on trans issues. Witch-hunts today may not end at the stake or on the ducking stool, but they still stle voices with breath­taking ease. Call someone a witch and they are a witch…because how can they prove that they’re not  So, perhaps it’s time to ditch the pointy hats and besoms and find a new look for Halloween. To give the real “witches” back their dignity and humanity. title: eleven major cop26 talk sponsors
story: Exclusive: Eleven major COP talk sponsors produce more greenhouse gas pollution than entire UKThe COP summit, being billed as the last best hope to stop environmental damage, begins in Glasgow this weekThe talks in Glasgow are hoped to hold the key to unlocking the climate crisis Image: PAByPaul DobsonPatrick Hill:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsEleven major sponsors of the COP climate talks produced more greenhouse gas pollution last year than the whole UK, an investigation has revealed. The conference is being billed as the “last best hope” to stop global damage that threatens to wipe out coastal towns and cities and make critical areas of the planet uninhabitable. Last year the UK’s emissions total produced within the country was put at  million tonnes. But a probe has found that was overshadowed by the global output of  sponsors, understood to have poured millions of pounds each into the talks which open today in Glasgow. Just five – ScottishPower, Hitachi, Unilever, Reckitt and National Grid – recorded a combined carbon footprint of almost  million tonnes, matching % of the UK’s own total.  The damning figures were compiled by investigative website The Ferret, which is itself based in Glasgow. Former Green Party leader Caroline Lucas told the Sunday Mirror: “The Government is making hypocrisy the hallmark of its approach to the talks. “Far too many companies are talking up their environmental responsibility while in reality doing far too little. “They need to walk the talk and start implementing the policies needed to address an accelerating crisis.” The companies, described as “principal partners”, were all chosen by the UK Government – which is hosting the two-week climate summit. Officially called The  United Nations Climate Change Conference, it is the most signicant environmental summit since ’s Paris Agreement. Around , people will gather at the Scottish Event Campus . Among them are  heads of state – including US president Joe Biden, France’s Emmanuel Macron and ­Canada’s Justin Trudeau – as well as teen climate activist Greta Thunberg.The target is an international deal on climate goals, including net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by the middle of the century. A key aim is to prevent the global temperature from rising by more than .C. The  “principal partners” will be given signicant prominence at the event, staging  events of their own – giving a huge shop window to advertise themselves and to talk up their green credentials. The firms last night each issued statements defending their environmental record.  They insist they are all already making progress towards “ambitious” targets. And they warn that some emissions put down to them may have been double-counted, as direct and indirect emissions could overlap. The analysis broke down emissions into three categories. Scope One and Two cover those directly due to a firm’s operations, such as buildings, vehicles, electricity and heating. Scope Three are indirect, including goods and services it buys in, transportation, and use of its products.Spanish energy giant Iberdrola , parent company of ScottishPower, was the biggest polluter of the  – contributing more than . million tonnes. Despite ScottishPower boasting its portfolio is made up solely of renewable energy, Iberdrola has opened two fossil gas plants in Mexico since .And while it says % of its energy was from green sources in the first half of , it has faced criticism as Spain’s eighth biggest polluter – and causing water shortages in three towns.What do you make of this story  Join the debate in the comments below Japanese multinational Hitachi narrowly trailed Iberdrola with emissions of nearly . million tonnes. Third was Unilever , with more than  million tonnes. Research last year found the firm also produces , tonnes of plastic a year.But it has pledged to make all of its plastic packaging recyclable, reusable or compostable by , and cut all ties with palm-oil suppliers found to be responsible for Indonesian wildfires.Consumer goods firm Reckitt had emissions of nearly  million tonnes in . And it has been criticised for still using unsustainable palm oil.Reckitt claims  per cent of its  emissions were caused by use of its appliances in people’s homes.  And it claimed to have reduced the direct carbon footprint from its factories by  per cent since . National Grid ’s annual emissions narrowly trailed Reckitt, at just under  million tonnes. Its US operation has faced a backlash over plans to build a fracked gas storage and transport facility in New York.It says it is aiming for net-zero emissions by  and has achieved a % cut since . Lower emitters among the “principal partners” are Sainsbury’s, Glaxo­SmithKline, Microsoft, SSE, Sky and NatWest. Sainsbury’s did not publish a breakdown of indirect emissions for . Butthese remained the same as its - baseline figures, it would have topped  million tonnes.However, it is the only supermarket globally given the highest rating by the Climate Change Disclosure for taking action on climate change for seven consecutive years. It is also the retailer with the second-highest proportion of loose fruit and vegetables in Greenpeace rankings – and this week announced it was cutting five years from its target to become net zero, committing to  instead of . GlaxoSmithKline added nearly  million tonnes of emissions, while Microsoft produced more than  million tonnes. A partnership between Microsoft and oil giant ExxonMobil has been shown to risk an increase in its annual emissions by  per cent.The tech giant is also one of the biggest corporate buyers of flights despite running a video conferencing  – but says it is urging staff to use its Teams more and is launching a “focus on sustainability”. SSE emitted  million tonnes in , largely due to operating Peterhead power station.It says Peterhead is Scotland’s only major thermal power station and provides important system stability for the country’s electricity grid.  The firm says this lets more renewables projects go ahead, giving the plant a role in the energy transition.Broadcaster Sky produced more than two million tonnes, while the lowest of the  was NatWest – according to its sustainability report. However, the NatWest data appears not to take into account the emissions caused by its investment in fossil fuels projects to the tune of .billion between  and .NatWest funds are also linked to the Cerrejon coal mine in Colombia, one of the biggest in the world. Rebecca Newsom, Head of Politics at Greenpeace UK, said: “Companies must be put under much more pressure to align with the globally agreed goal to limit warming. “We need ambitious regulations without delay. Anything less would let companies off the hook and allow them to greenwash.”  The Ferret is an award-winning investigative journalism : Please visit theferret.scot subscribe  for more.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Hitachi Ltd.GlaxoSmithKline plcScottishpower PLCExxon Mobil CorporationMicrosoftNational Grid plcGreenpeace UKGreen PartyJoe BidenCaroline LucasDisclosureEnergyClimate changePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news inspirational-pride-britain-winners-including-"Pride of Britain: Carol Vorderman praises incredible winnersByNatasha Wynarczyk:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe most star-studded night of the year is back as the Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards takes place in person for the first time since .Tonight, more than  famous faces – including Prince Charles, Ant and Dec, Holly Willoughby, Ed Sheeran, Sharon Stone and Simon Cowell – will come together to celebrate our unsung heroes.And for the first time in Pride of Britain’s -year history, host Carol Vorderman will be joined onstage by a co-host, Ashley Banjo. Carol said: “The night will be a proper celebration.” Here, we reveal some of this year’s inspirational winners...Letime Achievement – Rosemary Cox, , WolverhamptonSuccessfully campaigned to set up the first Organ Donor Register in the UK, helping to save thousands of lives. After their -year-old son Peter died in  following a brain tumour, Rosemary and John Cox saw the need for a register for people who wish to donate their organs. Peter had asked before his death for his organs to be used to help others and his sacrice saved or transformed the lives of  people. Have your say on this story in the comment section But his parents found that although patients in need of a transplant were listed on a central NHS computer, there was no equivalent register for potential donors. Over the next five years, the couple from Wolverhampton and their daughter Christine launched their campaign, travelling the country fundraising, lobbying politicians and creating awareness for their cause. Their efforts culminated at the  Conservative Party Conference when Christine made an impassioned plea from the  for a register of donorsapos wishes. Health Secretary Virginia Bottomley pledged there and then to set up an NHS Organ Donor Register, which launched on th October . Today the number of people who have registered their organ donation decision on the NHS Organ Donor Register has reached over  million or % of the UK population. Meanwhile, since the register was established on the th October , over , people have donated their organs after their death and over , deceased donor transplants have taken place. Rosemary is now . Her husband John passed away in , but their son’s legacy lives on and she continues to campaign to promote the benefits of organ transplantation. When the NHS marked the register’s th anniversary in , it was revealed it had saved or transformed , lives. And over the last  months, NHS Blood and Transplant facilitated nearly , transplants.Special Recognition – Rob Allen, , Northampton Founded Sands United, an inspirational network of football teams where men who have lost babies and young children can come together to grieve. Rob and his we Charlotte’s third child Niamh was stillborn, days before her due date in . They were helped through their loss by the stillbirth charity Sands, but at one meeting, Rob counted  women and three men. Realising that grieving dads were finding it dficult to reach out for help, he organised a charity football match to raise funds for Sands, but also giving men an opportunity to come together and talk about their loss. The one-off game, featuring bereaved fathers, grandfathers, uncles and brothers, raised £,, but the emotional benefit for the players was even more signicant.  And so, Sands United was born, and entered a local league in Northampton. But Rob’s impact has spread far wider. Inspired by his example, there are now more than  Sands United teams across Britain. Each team’s kit is embroidered with the names of the babies they have lost, and hundreds of men, and their families, have been empowered to open up about their loss, and support each other through sport.This Morning Emergency Services Award – Stephen Warton, , CumbriaPart-time firefighter risked his le to e to the rescue of a teenager who had been submerged in icy waters for more than  minutes.Kacper Krauze, , had been attempting to swim across the River Eden in Appleby-in-Westmorland in February . The weather was unseasonably warm, but the icy water sent his body into shock, and he sank to the bottom of the river. Appleby fire and rescue officers, who are retained with full-time jobs including butcher and mechanic, were the first emergency responders on the scene. Crew manager Stephen, a painter and decorator, and firefighter John Bell went into the river, supported by colleagues David Anderton, Michael Dowding, Bradley Hall, James Wood and Neil Aitken from the river bank. After a short search they located Kacper under two to three metres of water. Unable to e down and reach him due to his safety gear, Stephen went against protocol and took off his flotation equipment and helmet so he could e fully and bring the boy to the surface. Kacper had been underwater for about  minutes, and when Stephen brought him to the bank, he was in cardiac arrest and severely hypothermic. Paramedics resuscitated him and he was flown by air ambulance to hospital, where he was placed in an induced coma. He spent several weeks in intensive care but has since made a steady recovery. Mum Wioletta said: “It’s a miracle he survived. Every day is a little bit better, and he’s slowly getting back to normalGood Morning Britain Young Fundraiser – Hughie Higginson, , and Freddie Xavi, , LancashireBest pals have raised more than £, after Hughie was diagnosed with Leukaemia and Freddie vowed to help him thank his doctors and nurses. Hughie was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia last September and began three years of treatment at the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital. He wanted to say thank you to the medics looking after him so he signed up for the hospital charity’s fundraising walk.  Sadly, on the day he was too ill to take part, which is when best pal Freddie stepped up. He devised his own fundraising challenge on behalf of his pal, running km every day in the  days leading up to Christmas. He completed the final km on Christmas morning, pounding the streets before opening his presents. Hughie summoned all his strength to join his mate on the final stretch so they could cross the line together, hand-in-hand. The football-mad boys’ inspirational friendship, and incredible fundraising efforts touched hearts in their Lancashire community and beyond, and the pair have now raised more than £,. Georgia Sleigh from the hospital charity said: “Freddie and Hughie are just incredible – words just don’t do justice to how inspiring they both are.”Child of Courage – Harmonie-Rose Allen, , BathQuadruple amputee given a % chance of survival as a toddler has inspired the nation with her courage and unbreakable spirit. Harmonie-Rose was  months old, and had recently taken her first steps, when she started coughing and struggling for breath. Doctors twice allowed her home from AE, but the next day, she went floppy and a rash appeared. This time she was blue lit to Bristol Children’s Hospital, but doctors did not knowshe would survive the journey. She arrived in a critical condition and her limbs had turned black. Meningococcal septicaemia had damaged her legs, arms and the tip of her nose, leaving surgeons with no choice but to amputate. She was given a % chance of survival, and her parents were asked for permission to turn off her le supportnecessary.  Since then, and after more than  operations, she has beaten the odds. With enormous public help and unique family support she has thrived and now loves writing, drawing as well as many sports including swimming, dancing, gymnastics.In , she crossed the finish line of the Bath Half Marathon on her prosthetics, raising £, for the children’s charity, Time Is Precious. During the first lockdown in , she completed her . challenge, tackling six things doctors said she’d never do because of her disabilities,  times. These were running, singing, drawing, swimming, gymnastics and jumping, and she raised more than £, for Meningitis Now. Her latest challenge this year was to scale a climbing wall  times and run m for the first time on her blades in a bid to raise £, for an accessible playground. In March she received her first bionic arm. One of her first jobs was to paint her new nails and it also means she can hold her mumaposs hand for the first time since she was a baby. Spirit of Adventure – Max Woosey, , North Devon“Tent Boy” Max has spent more than  nights sleeping under canvas, raising £, for his local hospice. Neighbour and family friend Rick Abbott was terminally ill with cancer when he gave Max a tent, and told him to “go have an adventure”. When Rick passed away, Max decided to do a sponsored camp out to raise money for the hospice which had cared for his friend in his final weeks.  In March , he set himself the target of sleeping in the tent until the end of lockdown and hoped he might raise £. As lockdown restrictions dragged on, Max refused to come in from the cold and donations poured into his JustGiving page. Now, nearly  months later, he is still on his fundraising mission. At pm each night, the -year-old puts on his pyjamas, collects up his teddies, the Beano and his torch, says goodnight to his parents and makes his way to the garden. The marathon camper has now been sleeping outdoors for more than  nights, braving sub-zero frosts, heatwaves, and even Storm Bella. He has raised more than £, for North Devon Hospice, enough to pay for  community nurses and cover more than half the hospice’s estimated losses due to the pandemic. Max has also inspired thousands of other children to take part in a Big Camp Out for Action For Children,Special Recognition – Gee Walker, , LiverpoolForgave her son’s killers and devoted her le to promoting racial harmony in his memory, building a legacy of love to overcome hate. The brutal racist murder of Anthony Walker in  shocked the nation. The -year-old aspiring lawyer was chased from a bus stop in Huyton, Merseyside and killed with an ice pick in an unprovoked attack. His mum Gee refused to let her le, and Anthony’s memory, be consumed by bitterness, declaring of his killers: I forgive them. I don’t hate them. Hate is what killed my son. I am in enough pain. Why take on and carry about hate and anger as well ”  Her actions in the following  years have been just as powerful as her words. She founded the Anthony Walker Foundation in  to combat racism and offer a space for people to feel safe after suffering racial abuse. In the last five years, the Foundation has worked with nearly , young people through educational and outreach programmes in schools. Its victim support services have also helped nearly , people who have experienced hate crime while volunteers have engaged with thousands in a bid to build safer, stronger communities. Despite her achievements on a national scale, when asked what she is most proud of, she says simply: “Being a mum and a nan”Environmental Champion – Amy and Ella Meek,  and , NottinghamCampaigning sisters set up a kid’s charity to help fight the global scourge of plastic pollution. Amy and Ella are the founders of youth social action group Kids Against Plastic, which is now a registered charity. It calls for action against plastic pollution and encourages iniduals, schools and businesses to be more ‘plastic clever’ and ditch single-use plastics where possible. So far more than , schools and  cafes, businesses, festivals and councils have committed to being ‘plastic clever’. The sisters, from Nottingham, have given TED talks, spoken with leaders in the aviation industry about reducing their plastic footprint, addressed politicians in the House of Commons and spoken at the United Nations’ Young Activist Summit in December . Theyaposve personally collected , pieces of rubbish, one for every sea mammal killed by plastic pollution every year, and run a scheme to champion other anti-plastic activists who do the same around the country. Their first book, Be Plastic Clever, has just been published.Prince’s Trust Young Achiever – Hassan Alkhawam, , Northern IrelandWhen Hassan Alkhawam, aged , and his family fled their home in Syria due to the war, they were given refugee status and rehomed in Northern Ireland in . Since arriving in the country, Hassan has transformed his le. He is now studying Software Engineering at university and has been a key worker in Tesco during the Covid  pandemic. Before coming to Northern Ireland, Hassan’s father became ill and was no longer able to work, meaning Hassan had to leave full-time education and get a job to support the family. When he arrived in Northern Ireland, Hassan wanted toto education and fulfil his dream of going to university but needed to take an English language course before he could apply.  At the time, Hassan was not working and didn’t have money to pay for the course. A friend told him about The Prince’s Trust and Hassan got in touch to seethey could help. He took part in The Prince’s Trust Get into Retail programme, a training and mentoring scheme that gives young people the skills, experience, and confidence they need to find a job. After completing the four-week programme he was offered a job and started working there just before the pandemic began. As well as working part time and studying, Hassan is a voluntary Director of a local charity, NI Hyatt, that supports vulnerable members of the refugee and migrant communities. He has recently completed courses in advocacy and interpreting so that he can help this community settle into le in Northern Ireland. news uk-news kate-middletons-kind-gesture-help-"Ant McPartlin opens up to Kate Middleton about his past addictionsByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWhen the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced they were stepping down as senior members of the royal family, it came as a shock to their loved ones. But The Firm remained stalwart and continued with their royal duties in public as usual, attending events and showing their faces. On event saw Harry and Meghan reunite with The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge for the first time in public since the bombshell announcement. The Commonwealth Day Service at Westminster Abbey, held shortly before lockdown on  March , was Harry and Meghanaposs final outing before they jetted off to LA.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Sadly, it wasnapost quite the happy reunion weaposd hoped for and was reportedly marred by tensions behind the scenes. The pair had hoped to remain part of the Queenaposs procession at the beginning of the service. Instead, they were shown to their seats like all the other guests, which reportedly led them to be upset and emotional. However, the Daily Mail reports that, in a bid to smooth things over, Wills and Kate made a last minute change to the running order. The couple offered to skip the procession and join the Sussexes in their seats so they could all wait together for the service to start.  The decision was made so last minute that the order of services was already being printed - meaning they ended up being inaccurate. Sadly, itaposs reported their gesture didnapost have the desired effect and the meeting of the two couples appeared somewhat awkward. The Sussexes arrived first and sat in the second row. The Cambridges were shortly behind them, but Meghan and Harry didnapost stand to greet them. During the  ceremony Meghan and Kate greeted each other with a kiss on each cheek, but they seemed more reserved at this event. While it wouldnapost have been possible for them to kiss, the two couples exchanged only one or two words as they waited for the Queen and Prince Charles to arrive.  Meghan, who was already sitting down, could be seen saying hello and giving an awkward wave. Harry also said hello, but that was as far as their conversation went, with Harry turning to talk to his we. Then Sophie Wessex, who was sat behind Kate, leaned forward to chat to the Duchess while Harry and Meghan spoke to Prince Edward. There had been rumours of a rt between the two couples in the months leading up to Meghan and Harry announcing their intention to step down. These were fuelled when the couple scrapped their plans to live at Kensington Palace, just a few doors down from the Cambridges, and moved to Windsor instead. William and his dad Prince Charles were reportedly incandescent with rage when they were sent their announcement just  minutes before it was shared with the world. title: man grabs jogger 42 during
story: Man grabs jogger, , during run and pushes her into canal as police launch huntGreater Manchester Police say enquiries have establishedthe victim, a -year-old woman, was running on the footpath towards Castleton Train Station when she was approached by the manRochdale Canal at Lock  Image: Manchester Evening NewsByHelena VestyGraeme Murray:,  Oct | commentsA man grabbed a jogger and assaulted her before pushing into the canal Police have launched a hunt for the suspect who struggled with the woman before pushing her into the water. Manchester Evening News reports that the attack happened around .pm on Tuesday when police were called to the footpath of Rochdale Canal.Greater Manchester Police say enquiries have established that the victim, a -year-old woman, was running on the footpath towards Castleton Train Station when she was approached. The man grabbed the woman and she tried to get away. After a struggle between the two, he pushed the woman into the canal before running off towards Gorrels Way.  The woman did not suffer any injuries, but she was left understandably shaken by the incident, say police. They have issued a description of the man and are continuing their enquiries. He is described as being white, around ft ins tall and aged in his s. The man was also said said to be of a medium build and has a short back and sides haircut with scruffy, wavy hair on top. He was wearing light grey jogging bottoms, a dark coloured Parka jacket with a furry hood and dark trainers with air bubbles on the bottom. No arrests have been made over the incident and enquiries are ongoing.  Detective Constable Chris Davies, of GMPaposs Rochdale district, said: This was a terrying experience for the woman, who was left feeling violated and scared. We will absolutely not tolerate this behaviour in Greater Manchester and are following all available lines of enquiry to locate the offender as soon as possible. Extra patrols will be present in the area whilst enquiries are ongoing. If you have any concerns or questions please feel to speak to our officers. title: meet van lifers brits who
story: Meet the Van Lers - the Brits who gave up their homes to live on the roadNomadland, the Oscar-winning  film, has sparked a Staycation boom of people heading away for a holiday on the road - but some people do it full timeTasha Bee with her converted vanByLaura Connor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsNomadland, the Oscar-winning triumph of , shone a light on the highs and lows on living off the grid but on the move.Now “van le” has become the UK’s biggest staycation trend, with hundreds of Facebook groups devoted to self-builds.But for some people, the trend is more than a quirky post-lockdown holiday – it’s a way of le. New book VanLers shows how people have created incredible campers on a budget, transforming fire trucks, horseboxes and even ambulances. Here, we meet a few van le converts.Have you given everything up for a le on the road  Email webnews@mirror It took two months for Mark Bonito and Sophie Why to transform an old ambulance destined for the scrap heap. The couple were already living in a campervan part-time when they bought the Fiat Ducato at auction with all of its le-saving kit still inside. The couple, from Surrey, spent £, turning the ambulance into their new home – and called it Florence, after hero nurse Florence Nightingale. Sophie, , who works as a radiographer, says: “When it arrived, the inside was a treasure trove.  Everything was still in place – the stretcher, fold-away seats… even the cupboards with labels indicating what had previously lived in each one. “My personal favourites were the cupboards labelled ‘vomit bowl’ and ‘body bag’. “We are regularly asked whether the van is haunted or told how disgusting it is because of the nature of what happens in the back of an ambulance. “But we prefer to see the positive side of it and remind people of the number of iniduals our ambulance has helped to save, racing along, lights flashing, sirens blaring.”  Artist Tasha Bee, , converted her van into a mobile pottery studio, allowing her to put on workshops across the country. The van, called Daphne, is the third to be renovated by creative Tasha but her first fully converted vehicle. Tasha says: “I had quite a clear aesthetic vision for this project and have loved the process of bringing it into reality. I’ve learned a lot along the way. There are still quite a few bits and pieces that I want to do as well, so it’s an ongoing project.” Tasha, who is based in Bristol, set up a Crowdfunder campaign to raise funds for her portable business, called Pot Heads Pottery. Her target was £, and she raised slightly more than that, allowing her to install an electrical system in the van, which comes complete with an s-inspired theme. “I think the most unique thing about Daphne is her colourful paint job,” Tasha says. “I sometimes forget when I’m driving around in her and wonder why people are looking at me with a funny smile on their faces – then I remember that I’m in a big flowery van!”  Former lorry driver Charlie Glover was living in his nan’s spare room when he bought his “faded and rusty” truck for £, back in . The -year-old gradually kitted out the vehicle by skip-ing, upcycling and getting hand-me-downs from friends. Its sound system is salvaged from a nightclub, fresh water is stored in beer kegs and the kitchen is made from pallets. Charlie, of Cheltenham, Glos, who now runs his own van conversion company called RanVanga, says: “At the start, it definitely wasn’t comfortable. It was cold and had no heating, toilet or shower, but I loved the process. “Some nights were awful, but when the sun shines and you remember you’re making your own home, it makes it all worthwhile.”  RAF veteran Dr Sophie Cook, , traded her two-bed flat for a -year-old horsebox after struggling to pay her rent during lockdown. After years of dreaming about le on the road, she snapped up her  Ford Cargo Horsebox for £,. And Sophie, who was known as Steve until , affectionately named her horsebox Betty Blue. Since moving in, Sophie has mucked out the van to create a cosy mobile home and replaced bench seating with a sofa bed in the lounge area. Sophie, the former club photographer at AFC Bournemouth, says: “I love to roam. One day soon I hope to cross the sea and travel.”  Jess and Dave Branton always wanted to convert their own vehicle, so when they saw an advert for a fire truck nearby, it was impossible to resist. The van was delivered to their drive the very next day and the couple spent £, converting it into their dream mobile home, complete with shower room, composting loo, gas cylinder, log burner and solar-powered system. Jess, , and Dave, , then took the plunge and put their house on the market in order to live in the fire truck full-time with their daughters Poppy, , and five-year-old Luna. At first, the family stayed close to friends and family in Lincoln, but they have since clocked up more than , miles travelling through Europe. Jess says: “At first we quietly resided in woodland and enjoyed true off-grid van le, homeschooling and rewilding with nature. “The future for the fire truck family is exciting – lots more travelling and living freely.”VanLers: Beautul Conversions for Le on the Road, edited by Alex Waite, is published by The History Press, RRP £.Comment MORE ON Staycation" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news meghan-markle-harry-dropped-hints-"Meghan and Harry rely on celebrity status says SacerdotiByBenedict Tetzlaff-DeasChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry could have dropped hints about leaving the Royal Family years before quitting the Firm and leaving the UK.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex caught fans by surprise in January  when they announced their plans to step down as senior royals and become financially independent.Since then, the pair have moved from the UK to Calornia with their son Archie and in June this year, they welcomed their daughter Lilibet. Harry and Meghan met in  and tied the knot in May  - two years before leaving royal le.In a  interview, Meghan - who was still an actress in Suits at the time - made some comments that somehow seemed to foreshadow her and Harryaposs future decision to become independent, the Daily Star reports. She told InStyle: I think the biggest part of being a girl boss in the office, at home, or anywhere you go is just knowing your value. As you get older, you become more comfortable in your skin and comfortable in saying aposnoapos to things...Itaposs something that, I think, comes with age and really having a sense of your self-worth. And then you make choices based on that. During an interview Harry and Meghan gave in  while on a trip in South Africa, the Duchess of Sussex admitted she was not okay. She made the admission in a chat with ITVaposs Tom Bradby about the pressures of her new role as a royal mum, appearing to hold back tears.  Meghan was asked about the true pressures of le in the spotlight and the toll it has taken on them both.She said at the time:Look, any woman especially when they are pregnant you’re really vulnerable and so that was made really challenging, and then when you have a newborn – you know.And especially as a woman, it’s a lot. So you add this on top of just trying to be a new mom or trying to be a newlywed it’s, well... She then thanked Tom for asking how she felt, saying: And, also thank you for asking, because not many people have askedI’m OK. But it’s a very real thing to be going through behind the scenes.  The comments seem to suggest that the possibility of leaving the Royal Family was on their minds for some time before they announced they would step down. This year Harry, , also admitted that he had thought about quitting the Firm in his twenties. He told actor Dax Shepard on the Armchair Expert podcast: In my early s, it was a case of, aposI donapost want this job, I donapost want to be here, I donapost want to be doing this, look what it did to my mumapos. In a statement released on social media in January  to announce their decision of quitting royal le, the Sussexes said: After many months of reflection and internal discussions, we have chosen to make a transition this year in starting to carve out a progressive new role within this institution.  We intend to step back as ‘senior’ members of the Royal Family and work to become financially independent, while continuing to fully support Her Majesty The Queen. It is with your encouragement, particularly over the last few years, that we feel prepared to make this adjustment. We now plan to balance our time between the United Kingdom and North America, continuing to honour our duty to The Queen, the Commonwealth, and our patronages. The couple went on to discuss Archie and their plans to raise him with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born. They said: This geographic balance will enable us to raise our son with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born, while also providing our family with the space to focus on the next chapter, including the launch of our new charitable entity. We look forward to sharing the full details of this exciting next step in due course, as we continue to collaborate with Her Majesty The Queen, The Prince of Wales, The Duke of Cambridge and all relevant parties. Until then, please accept our deepest thanks for your continued support. title: meghan markle princess diana share
story: Meghan Markle and Princess Diana share same trajectory, royal biographer claimsThere are similarities between Meghan Markle and Princess Diana because both struggled emotionally and mentally in the Royal Family, Andrew Morton said during an interviewMeghan Markle at a garden party at Buckingham Palace in May  Image: PAByChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsMeghan Markle and Princess Diana share the same trajectory in the public spotlight, a royal biographer has claimed.Andrew Morton said there are similarities between the Duchess of Sussex and her late mother-in-law, who died in  when Prince Harry was .The royal author, whose biography aposDiana: Her True Storyapos was a New York Times bestseller when it was first published in , said he observes striking similarities between the Duchess of Sussex and Princess Diana.During an interview with Good Morning America, Mr Morton said both Meghan and Diana struggled emotionally and mentally in the Royal Family.He told GMA: Meghanaposs gone from aposDuchess Dazzlingapos to aposDuchess Dficult,apos exactly the same trajectory happened with Diana.  And both of them were struggling emotionally and mentally to cope with, first of all, being pregnant, but also with le inside this goldfish bowl of the Royal Family. The royal biographer added that one of the biggest misconceptions about Meghan is that she was in control of their lives while they were senior royals, but actually, Prince Harry was the real expert.He explained:Meghan Markle is blamed for Harry coming to Hollywood. When ironically, it was Harry who was very keen to do an interview with Oprah. Mr Morton added: So she has deferred to him and often got the blame for things that have gone wrong. Sadly for Meghan, thereaposs a narrative thataposs built up thataposs wholly negative towards her.Last month, Meghan paid a subtle tribute to Princess Diana as she rounded off a trip to New York City with Harry.She carried a black Christian Dior Lady D-Lite bag that Diana liked and also wore her Cartier Tank watch. In her book aposThe Benchapos, which was published in June this year, Meghan also paid tribute to Diana with a picture of her favourite flowers.Meghan told NPR : “I think you can find sweet little moments that we hid in there – of my favourite flower, even my husband’s mom’s favourite flower, forget-me-nots.“We wanted to make sure those were included in there. There are many, many special details and love that went into this book.” Comment MORE ON Meghan MarkleAndrew MortonPrincess DianaPrince HarryRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
