news uk-news mum--kids-including-autistic-"Northfield: Beckie Searle is about to lose her rented homeByAndy RichardsonMatthew DreschReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum and her four children, including an autistic son, face being made homeless after her landlord sold their home. Beckie Searle, from Birmingham, is currently living in private rented accommodation but must leave by November .She cannot afford to continue private renting and has been told it could take months for her to find a council home, BirminghamLive reports.Birmingham City Council said there is a shortage of properties in the city and it is encouraging residents to look at the private market. Single mum Beckie, , has four children, Tyler aged , Jodie, aged , eight-year-old Kaine and five-year-old Leyla. Kaine is autistic and the strain on the family is having a particularly negative affect on him.  Jodie suffers from bronchitis and Leyla has mobility problems. Beckie has contacted Birmingham City Council for help but has been told she could face months to find a new home. The mum says private renting is too expensive and now faces splitting her young family up - a decision which she says will break her heart. The family have already packed up their belongings and are just counting the days until they have to leave their home. Beckie, who is currently claiming Universal Credit but is looking to go back to work as a support worker, said: The family will be split up as I will have to put them all up at dferent houses within our family. I need my autistic son settled.He is getting more aggressive than he usually is because of the situation. He doesnapost like to leave his bedroom because he doesnapost knowthat will be the last time he will see it. Two of my other children also have health problems. I have gone through the homeless department at the council but have told me that I have to wait six weeks before I get a bidding number to bid for a house. They have told me to private rent. I just canapost afford the prices. I canapost afford £ per month for a four bedroomed house. My wages would just not cover it.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter I feel absolutely wounded by whataposs happened. Itaposs just going to be a massive upheaval for everyone. A spokesman for Birmingham City Council said: We are very sorry to hear that this family is being made homeless. Anyone being asked to leave a rented property should seek legal advice on what this means in terms of the circumstances under which they may need to leave. This can sought from a housing law solicitor or through Birmingham City Council’s Housing Solutions service. If a household is at risk of homelessness the Housing Solutions service will assess the circumstances and determine in what way they may be assisted.  Demand for housing in Birmingham is considerably greater than supply, this does regularly result in households who are homeless, being placed in emergency accommodation including BB’s, until a alternative option can be secured. We do encourage households to look at other options. To help with renting in the Private Rented Sector we have introduced a new scheme with HelpRent, an organisation that makes housing simple for tenants and landlords and provides incentives to landlords who offer -month fixed tenancies to those on the Council’s homeless and housing registers. More information about HelpRent is on our website. title: mum children burgle neighbours home
story: Mum let children burgle neighbours home before they left human waste on floorThe judge gave her a suspended sentence saying he has done what he can to help the mother save her family. He told her she needed to control her children before they end up in careThe victims home was ransacked Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByKelly-Ann MillsReporterEsther Halligan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A mum has denied being with her children when they broke into a neighbouraposs home and ransacked it, leaving human excrement and smashed eggs on the kitchen floor. The children stole whatever they could find from the house, before drawing on the walls and leaving cigarette butts in the bathroom sink, a court was told. There was also apple juice thrown over the bed and coal trodden into the carpet.Teesside Crown Court heard that the victim had taken advantage of the lting of lockdown restrictions to go and visit her mother. But one of the victimaposs neighbour noticed the back gate was ajar and saw children coming and going from the house and alerted the police.Not long after the police had left the neighbouraposs house, she heard a childaposs voice from the house next door shouting: Theyaposve goneaposapos.The victim ed home to find her watch, make up, perfume, books and toys missing, Teesside Live reports.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Even a packet of noodles was stolen from the kitchen during the raid in Teesside in last year. One of the children was seen heavily made-up and wearing the victimaposs jumper and scarf a few days after the burglary. The police searched the motheraposs home and recovered some of the victimaposs belongings. The mother, who is in her s and cannot be named for legal reasons, pleaded guilty to the burglary on the day her trial was due to start. Defending, Samuel Ponniah told the court that the single mum had been, aposaposoverwhelmed looking after her children during lockdownaposapos when she was also pregnant.  The mum claimed she had only gone into her neighbouraposs house to get her children out, and that she had not taken part in the burglary. The mum stood at the back of the court in a tracksuit, crying and and talking to the dock officer next to her. Judge Jonathan Carroll told her to pay attention to proceedings, adding: aposaposYour le is almost a basket case. Youaposve got children, but you are the adult. I donapost have a magic wand to fix your situation at all. You have to be in control of your children - they need their mother. If I send you to prison, your children would go into care. That is a catastrophic and overwhelming consequence for the children. Youaposve got a long road ahead of you. You need signicant intervention.  The judge handed the woman a -week prison term suspended for two years, and a supervision order. The mum will take part in the, aposWomenaposs Service Programmeapos and mustto court in January , when the judge has requested a report on how she is integrating into the help provided. She must also attend  rehabilitation days. The judge added: aposaposIaposve done what I can to help you save your familyaposapos. title: mum turns home retro paradise
story: Exclusive: Mum turns home into retro paradise with sixties features and psychedelic printsLizzie loves the s  s Image: Simon Jacobs Mercury PressByJade Culver:,  Oct | commentsA mum who is convinced she was born in the wrong decade has turned her home into a retro paradise. Lizzie Mullaney, , has decorated her home in London with vibrant oranges, funky patterns, and psychedelic prints. Her retro obsession is also reflected in her wardrobe - packed with flared pants, polo necks and huge shades. The interior designer shares her passion for seventies fashion with her husband Leon, , who runs a fire protection service, daughter Dita, four, and stepson Jarvis, . She said: “I’m very inspired by old films such as Blow Up, and those based in the sixties and seventies such as Once Upon A Time in Hollywood, Valley of the Dolls and Boogie Nights. What do you think of the house  Have your say in the comment section “I wanted to recreate that vibe within my home to match how I dress every day. “I found that, during lockdown, decorating was a great way to stay positive, it started with one room and just progressed from there.” Thrty Lizzie raided charity shops and upcycled old furniture to give her home its vintage vibe. She said: “I really tried to stick to a budget, so a lot of furniture and accessories are from charity shops and I also upcycled a lot of furniture and even reupholstered this old chair I had.  “I aimed to spend less than £ a month and I’ve tried to decorate the house with little bits that I love. “I also inherited lots of homeware from my late grandma, which really fits with the look I was aiming for. “I wanted to create a bit of escapism, and I haven’t left a wall untouched. “I’ve been shopping vintage for the past fteen years, and because I’m a bargain queen, I love to raid the £ or fewer rails.  Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters “Because I’ve been wearing seventies style clothes for so long, I really couldn’t put a figure to how much my wardrobe is worth, but I love to buy second hand and independent [clothes]. “I love flared pants and polo necks, and I always make sure I’ve got my big pair of oversized glasses. “I try my best to avoid fast fashion, and wearing vintage clothes is the most sustainable and ethical way to be. “If something doesn’t fit me properly anymore, orI like the pattern but not the item itself, I like to upcycle it to make something new.  “Orit’s just a pair of trousers that are too long, it’s very easy to patch them up to the right size.” Lizzie’s house now boasts floor to ceiling prints, a seventies tan couch and a vintage Mediterranean kitchen. Focusing on bright colours and bold shapes, Lizzie incorporated oranges, pinks and greens with retro floral patterns and little art deco prints into her home renovation. She even gets her kids and husband involved in the fun, from decorating the house to copying her seventies look. She said: “Dita loves matching with me, and when we’re out and about together people will come over to say how cute she looks. “I occasionally make my own outfits, and one time I made a matching set for myself and Dita, and a t-shirt for Jarvis so he could get involved. “I love to knit as well, and Jarvis helped me make quite a few scarves for friends and family last Christmas. “I just love that I get to be myself, and that my family love to join in, and that we are all being sustainable.” Comment MORE ON AccessoriesSunday PeopleVintage ClothingDream Homesproperty news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news mystery-bank-vault-door-filmed-"Spooky goings on in the vaults of abandoned bankByKelly-Ann MillsReporterGraham Young:,  Oct | commentsA former bank vault door has been filmed moving in the middle of the night deep below a city centre, leaving staff to scared to venture downstairs.The vape shop workers, who claim a video of the heavy door is not a Halloween trick, say they often hear funny noises and believe the basement which is home to the shopaposs staff toilets has a strange atmosphere. The three-year-old vaping company moved to a new address on Bennetts Hill, Birmingham between the Cosy Cluband JD Wetherspoonaposs The Briar Rose pub.But just days later bosses installed CCTV cameras all over the premises, which was first built in . Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter According to local legend, the building first became a watering hole in  and the then Bodega wine bar was popular with sportsmen and thespians.On December , , publican Henry Skinner reputedly made the mistake of crossing brothers Herbert and Arthur Allen, Birmingham Live reports.Arthur worked at the pub but was sacked on the spot and a furious row over wages erupted. In a fit of rage his brother grabbed a gun and blasted the landlord in the cellar. The legend goes on that Henry - the ghost - wears a bowler hat and there were said to be two more ghosts upstairs – of two girls who fell to their deaths.  Known as The Trocadero since , a man behind the bar said: Those stories were made up. Iaposve been here for years and not seen anything. Lewis Felstead, one of the directors of e-liquids, set up a series of security cameras and couldnapost believe what he saw on Monday morning this week. Lewis said: We were putting a new office in upstairs and discovered this space down here. The builders didnapost almost want to be in here to explore because they were hearing strange noises.  When they came down here they would often come straight back up so with that we werenapost sure what was going on. We needed to know what was happening with the building and thataposs when we put in the expensive cameras. We found that things were moving on their own, including this door. It sends a shiver down my spine being stuck here in this spaceIaposm honest.  When you come down here you can feel the atmosphere change in this space. One of our female colleagues was one of the first to come down here to have a look, but one of the first to run back up and to let everyone know what the experience was like. That was part of the trigger for looking to investigate further. title: northern lights visible parts uk
story: Northern Lights visible from parts of the UK tonight following massive solar flareA huge burst of radiation from the sun on October  is due to reach the Earth tonight after a  million mile journey, meaning a colourful display of the Northern Lights may well be visible above the UKThe Northern Lights may be visible in the UK tonight Image: PAByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments People in the UK may be treated to a spectacular natural display tonightthe Northern Lights appear over the isles. Scientists have tipped tonight - the day before Halloween - to be a magical one thanks to solar flares.A huge burst of radiation from the sun on October  is due to reach the Earth tonight after a  million mile journey. The cloud of electromagnetic particles will cause a colourful display in the atmosphere which may be visible from parts of the Northern Hemisphere.If you see the Northern Lights tonight, send your photos to webnews@mirror The best vantage points will fall across Iceland, Scotland, Norway, Alaska, Canada and Michigan in the US, C Alex Young, NASAaposs Heliophysics Division associate director at the Goddard Space Flight Centre in Maryland, said. The best chance of seeing the phenomenon will be around am, when it is usually the darkest.Luckily the Met Office has forecasted that there will be little to no cloud cover tonight, meaning the view wonapost be blocked.The Northern Lights tend to shine brightest the further north you are, meaning those in the south of England probably wonapost get much of a display.  This is primarily because the planetaposs poles conduct the most electromagnetic energy. The solar discharge could impact some of the planetaposs orbiting satellite arrays, meaning some mobile devices may stop working temporarily. When the Sun first loosed its latest flare, it caused a near-immediate impact in South America. Most of the continent, at the time facing the star, briefly lost radio capabilities.  Solar flares are ided into categories according to their strength and the one that was fired off on Thursday was an X-class. They are classied in a letter system, with C-class being relatively weak, M-class moderate and X-class flares as the strongest. Among X-class ones, “an X is twice as intense as an X, an X is three times as intense”, according to NASA. The one currently headed towards Earth is an X flare which, despite being the least intense of the X-class flares, is likely wreak havoc by interfering with radio and satellite communications. title: pride britain winning oxford astrazeneca
story: Exclusive: Pride of Britain-winning Oxford-AstraZeneca jab heroes lived off Mini CheddarsTonight, the hard work of the Oxford-AstraZeneca team was ­rewarded with the Pride of Britain Special Recognition prize - one billion doses of their vaccine have been delivered to  countriesThe Oxford vaccine team won the Special Recognition award at the Daily Mirrors Pride of Britain AwardsByLaura Connor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Oxford-AstraZeneca team were fuelled by vending machine snacks as they worked around the clock to develop their le-saving Covid jab. Producing a vaccine normally takes  years but the dedicated staff put in -hour days – and lived off Mini Cheddars and Bounty bars – to turn it around in just  months. Tonight, their hard work was ­rewarded with the Pride of Britain Special Recognition prize, in partnership with TSB. Six members of the -plus team of leading scientists accepted the award at the ceremony in London. Among those walking the red carpet was Dr Catherine Green, who manufactured the first vaccine.What do you think of this yearaposs winners  Have your say in the comment section She said: “The vaccine was always ­going to be the way out of the pandemic and here we are! “We wanted to walk the red carpet as a team because that’s what a was – a team effort. The university went into lockdown so we were living off the ­vending ­machines, eating Mini Cheddars and Bounty bars. “It feels great to be finally letting our hair down after the last  months.”  Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters And Prof Theresa Lambe, who co-designed the vaccine, added: “I know it sounds really boring but we were just doing our day jobs and we hoped it would help. We’re really glad it did so people can come together again on an amazing night like this.” Dr Sandy Douglas, the brains behind the process of mass-­developing the jab, said: “To receive this award means a lot ­because more than anything, it was the most amazing teamwork.” So far, one billion doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine have been delivered to  countries around the world. It is estimated to have saved more than , lives in the UK alone. Dr Douglas added: “We knew we had a chance that we might be able to do something extraordinary. “Me and my colleagues knew thousands of people were going to die each daywe didn’t act fast, so every day we were faster, the more lives we saved.” Comment MORE ON Transportation Safety Board of CanadaPride of Britain Awards" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: princess anne accused mockery cop26
story: Exclusive: Princess Anne making mockery of COP royals with  helicopter trips in  daysA source tells the Sunday People tha it seems Princess Anne does not share the climate concerns of Prince William, Prince Charles and the Queen and is more Donald Trumpthan Greta ThunbergPrincess Anne seen boarding the royal helicopter in Plymouth this week Image: Matt GilleyByPatrick HillMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Princess Anne is accused of making a mockery of the Royal family ’s eco credentials by taking at least three helicopter flights in  days earlier this month.Her journeys included drop-offs in Forres, Scotland, on October , Weston-super-Mare on October  and Plymouth on October .A source tonight told the Sunday People : “ Prince William, Prince Charles and the Queen have all spoken out about the climate emergency in recent weeks, but it seems that Anne doesn’t share their concerns. “Her actions somewhat make a mockery of her family’s campaigning at COP.“It’s safe to say Anne is more Donald Trump than Greta Thunberg when it comes to these matters.” What do you think about Anneaposs trips  Have your say in the comment section Experts say Anne’s trips caused carbon emissions of around . tonnes, used hundreds of gallons of aviation fuel and cost at least £,. It is estimated the Queen’s daughter could have cut her carbon footprint down to an estimated . tonnesshe had made the same journeys by car. Prince William and Prince Charles are set to be key attendees during events at COP and the Queen was also planning to go before being ordered to rest for two weeks by her doctors.  Get the latest royal news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters She will still give a virtual speech at a banquet organised for world leaders, heads of state and other VIP guests. But Anne will not be among them and has previously spoken out about her scepticism of climate change, as well as environmental disagreements she has with Charles. The future king, a long-time climate change activist, yesterday made a new appeal to the world, saying: “Sustainable urban development is clearly critical in responding to the climate emergency.”  By contrast, in an interview with Australian Women’s Weekly to mark her th birthday last year, Anne said: “I don’t even go down the climate change route. “I think the way people manage ground is part of the discussion. “Climate changes all the time. It has done so throughout the globe’s history, so there’s nothing new under the sun.” Anne was also forthright over veganism, adding: “You can’t have a world without livestock. They are a necessary and very constructive part of our expectation to feed ourselves.” Flights records show Anne’s trips were among at least  separate journeys made by the Queen’s choppers in October, including by Charles and Camilla during a royal visit to Scotland. The prince has himself come in for criticism for his use of helicopters, including last year when he flew  miles to talk about lowering aircraft emissions. A Buckingham Palace spokesperson said: “Official travel for members of the Royal Family seeks to find the best balance of security and efficiency whilst minimising any disruption to the public. “On some occasions, when all factors are considered, a helicopter provides the best option for travel for official engagements.” Comment MORE ON Buckingham PalaceAnne, Princess RoyalPrince Charles, Prince of WalesPrince WilliamRoyal FamilyClimate changeSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: queen tells family remains totally
story: Exclusive: Queen tells family she remains totally committed to hosting Christmas at SandringhamThe Queen has been forced to pull out of several royal engagements, including her scheduled appearance at the COP climate change conference, as she rests following ill healthThe Queen is said to be totally committed to hosting a family Christmas Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Queen has told her family she will host Christmas at Sandringham after she has rested up on the advice of royal doctors. The monarch is said to be “totally committed” to entertaining her loved ones at her Norfolk home after missing out last year because of the pandemic. On Friday it was revealed Her Majesty, , has cancelled all working visits for the next two weeks and has been advised to stick to “light, desk-based duties”. It means several of her royal engagements have been cancelled, including the COP climate change conference which starts in Glasgow today. The Queen, who has recently used a walking stick for the first time on royal visits, is recovering after she had tests and spent a night in hospital earlier this month. But royal sources said she is determined to recover soon so she can see her family at their traditional festive gathering. Last year restrictions meant the Queen and the late Prince Philip had a quiet Christmas alone at Windsor Castle.But after losing her husband of  years in April, it is understood Her Majesty really wants to see everyone together. A Palace insider said: “This year, more than ever, it is incredibly important to Her Majesty to be surrounded by her loved ones. “The Queen is totally committed to hosting everyone as she hopes to make it back to full health in the coming weeks. “Her Majesty is resting under doctors’ orders with the intention of being able to fully enjoy the company of her extended family over the holiday period.  “After being forced to cancel a host of engagements, the family get-together will be the perfect tonic.” Royal aides insist the Queen is in “good spirits” and stress her medical team is simply taking “sensible precautions” with its latest advice. Buckingham Palace said on Friday doctors had advised Her Majesty to “continue to rest for at least the next two weeks”. It added the Queen had been advised she “can continue to undertake light, desk-based duties during this time...but not to undertake any official visits”Donapost miss the Mirroraposs regular royal podcast Pod Save The Queen, with royal correspondent Victoria Murphy and host Ann Gripper.Listen on iTunes, Audioboom and your favourite podcast apps.Catch up with Episode  - Royal Wedding Bells for Meghan and Harry.  The Palace added the Queen will “regretfully” not attend the Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall next Saturday. But it is her “firm intention” to be at the Cenotaph in London on Remembrance Sunday.Details of the Queen’s condition have been sparse, but Boris Johnson yesterday revealed she was “on very good form” when they spoke this week.Speaking in Rome, ahead of the G summit, the Prime Minister added: “Everybody wishes her all the very best.” Comment MORE ON Buckingham PalaceThe QueenRoyal FamilySandringham" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: spooky sea ghosts look like
story: Spooky ghosts that look like humans emerge from sea - leaving locals terriedLocals have been aware of the phenomenon for some time and been mildly disturbed by them, but a new picture of the marine ghouls have brought them to a larger audienceThe strange sea ghosts pictured off Anglesey which have left people spooked Image: Craig FaircloughByAndrew ForgraveGraeme Murray:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsaposSea ghostsapos which look like humans and only occasionally emerge from the water have left beachgoers terried. Like ghostly apparitions, rising from the deep, they appear only occasionally to spook passers-by on Anglesey’s northern coast. For much of the time the cluster of figures remain submerged beneath the Irish Sea, only to reappear like maritime Chewbaccas or the Crew of the Flying Dutchman. Now that Halloween is approaching, the human-like shapes at Newry Beach, Holyhead, have gained wider fascination on social media. Locals have been aware of the phenomenon for some time and been mildly disturbed by them but a new picture of the marine ghouls have brought them to a larger audience. One person told NorthWales Live they do a double-take every time they walk past the eerie group.Another said: “I wouldn’t like to see them on a dark evening, very spooky.” A third added: “Actually that’s quite scary.... especiallyseen in the moonlight.” The photo was taken by Craig Fairclough of Chester, a regular visitor to the area in his touring caravan.He told North Wales Live : “I was walking the dog along Newry Beach when I saw what looked like human bodies emerging from the water,” he said.“I thought it would make a good photo, so I grabbed my mobile phone.“It was a spur of the moment thing. After the picture was posted on Facebook, it was shared widely with people saying how unique and atmospheric it looked.”The aposghoulsapos are in fact a seaweed-covered cluster of old wooden pilings from Holyhead’s former leboat ramp.Nature has fashioned them into human shapes that now stand testimony to the bravery of leboat crews who have operated out of Holyhead since . Over the centuries the rocky coastline and strong currents have caught out many a ship in the treacherous shipping lanes leading from Liverpool and Dublin.In the  years after the station was taken over by the RNLI in , the station lost seven leboat crew members as they battled to reach floundering vessels in the Irish Sea.The old leboat ramp now lies next to Holyhead Maritime Museum, which moved into the former leboat house – the oldest surviving one in Wales – in . Craig’s photo of the museum’s ghostly neighbours have intrigued fans of MR James, the medievalist scholar best remembered for his ghost stories. On a fans forum, one said it proved that Wales was a place where it was easy to get spooked. “It is a beautul country, but you can feel a dark sadness in these wild places,” he wrote. “It is a unique sensation here, I feel.” Comment MORE ON Ghosts" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: student left needing walking stick
story: Student needed walking stick after being spiked - but GP accused her of drug useA diabetic fine art student says she felt let down by paramedics, doctors and her students union over how they handled it, and still feels "vulnerable" during nights out five years laterLancaster University graduate Polly Sutherland was  when she was spiked five years ago, but says she still feels vulnerable going out now Image: PAByKate Buck:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA fine art student who needed to use a walking stick after being spiked on a night out has said she feels let down with how paramedics, doctors and her studentaposs union handled the incident. Lancaster University graduate Polly Sutherland was  when she was spiked five years ago, but says she still feels vulnerable going out all these years later. Miss Sutherland, from Stone in Staffordshire, had been on a night out at the universityaposs The Sugarhouse, run by the studentsapos union, in December  when friends noticed her behaving strangely. The graduate, who also has type  diabetes, said being drugged left her needing to use a walking stick for around a month because it damaged her blood sugar levels - something which can be fatal for people with the condition.  It took away the use of her drawing hand for weeks. Recalling the night, Miss Sutherland, now , said: I donapost remember anything suspicious happening, or noticing anything happening. It was just, later in the night, friends with me noticed that my personality changed - I seemed very dferent... erratic. So they took me home, I went to bed, but when I woke up in the morning I had a lot of bodily weakness and twitches in my arms, legs, all over really. She went on: When I went tothey werenapost very helpful. I remember feeling really disappointed, because I went to them saying aposFrom whataposs going on, I think Iaposve been spikedapos.  They almost raised their eyebrows, almost accusing me of taking drugs, and I was trying to get out of it somehow or making excuses. I felt very let down by the doctors at that point. Miss Sutherland had to apply for deadline extensions in the final year of her art degree because she could not paint or draw following the incident. She said she reported the incident to Lancaster University Studentsapos Union , but received little response. Asked how the incident made her feel, she said: Very... I donapost want to use the word violated, because maybe thataposs too strong. But itaposs scary to think what could have happened. Iaposm lucky that I had a lot of friends around me that took me home when they noticed something wasnapost right, so Iaposm very thankful for that, because I donapost know what purpose that person went out with.  It made me feel very vulnerable. Even now, when I go on nights out, Iaposm very cautious of it now, and itaposs in the back of my mind all the time. The graduate, who is now in her second year of a politics degree at Keele University, said she has joined the Girls Night In movement, which sees students boycotting clubs following reports of drink spiking incidents. But she said: The thing that bothers me is that, with the boycotting, the onus is on girls, again, to stay in. I think the fact that we are the ones that have to stay in because this is happening is putting it on us, itaposs our responsibility to make sure we donapost get spiked, instead of telling people not to spike people. Miss Sutherland said clubs should use CCTV and scan ID cards on entry, instead of just checking them by eye, so that they have a record of who attended each night. In a statement, Lancaster University said: We pride ourselves on Lancaster being a safe place to study and are distressed to hear about any of our students being assaulted in this way. The Sugarhouse is owned and managed by Lancaster University Studentsapos Union, and we cannot comment on inidual incidents. However,any of our students have safety concerns in relation to spiking, or any other kind of assaults, then we would strongly encourage them to report them to the university and we have created a range of ways to enable our students to do so. We would also encourage students to report any such incidents to the police. title: superhero boy learning crawl after
story: Superhero boy learning to crawl after surgeons operated on him in the wombDoctors diagnosed Preston Mark Middleton, from Gateshead, with Spina Bida, a condition which causes a babys spine and spinal cord to develop improperly in the wombMark Middleton was born with spina Bida Image: chroniclelive BySophie Finnegan:,  Oct | commentsA apossuperheroapos boy who had surgery while in the womb is already learning to crawl despite a devastating diagnosis. Preston Mark Middleton was diagnosed with Spina Bida, a condition which causes a babyaposs spine and spinal cord to develop improperly in the womb.Doctors scanned mum Deborah and told her the unborn child had birth defect which can cause weakness or total paralysis of the legs, Chronicle Live reported. It also caused Chiari  malformation - a condition of the cerebellum that can put pressure on parts of the brain and spinal cord. In a bid to give Preston his best chance, Deborah underwent fetal surgery in Belgium when she was  weeks pregnant to repair his spine. And then at  weeks, Preston entered the world via a C-section. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He remained in intensive care while doctors monitored his progress before he was allowed tohome on December . The diagnosis came as a huge shock to Deborah and -year-old dad David, . Deborah said: When we got the diagnosis, they gave us quite a bleak outlook of children with Spina Bida. I was told Preston would not have a very good quality of le, he would not be able to do much for himself like walk and run. I know they have to give you the worst-case scenarios but we just found out our baby had got a condition, it was really dficult. They said we had a few options, the first option was a termination which was just horrendous.  Deborah said the family has been on a rollercoaster of emotions since Prestonaposs diagnosis but that the little boy is doing amazingly well. She said: It all happened in the middle of the pandemic, it feels a bit like a dream from getting the diagnosis to how he is now, heaposs doing amazing. Itaposs been a rollercoaster of emotions. Itaposs so hard because you donapost know whataposs going to happen or how he is going to do or what his le will be like. We were trying for two years before I became pregnant with Preston and itaposs supposed to be such a happy time but I was just so worried and stressed. You get to the point where you just accept the situation and deal with whatever comes next. We just told ourselves weaposre lucky heaposs been sent to us, heaposs extra special. As well as the emotional toll, Deborah also had a scare following the surgery after losing the use of her legs but luckily an emergency MRI scan revealed no long-term damage. She said: I couldnapost walk and had to use a wheelchair to get around. I went through surgery to give my son the best chance of walking and now I couldnapost walk. It was a really scary time but I was doing it for Preston so it was all worth it. Now, -months-old, Preston is doing amazingly well despite his condition and is already trying to crawl. Deborah said: We went for his first physio session and they were just blown away by him, heaposs just like a typical child.  Heaposs met all his milestones up to now. Walking is not something we are going to know about until it happens. Heaposs been doing amazingly well, heaposs been trying to crawl around, and seeing as heaposs been doing so well they do think he will walk. Heaposs the happiest little boy in the world, you would never think he had been through everything he has. In his  months heaposs been through more than some people have their whole letime but heaposs still the happiest little boy and he makes us all so proud every day. Deborah and her partner had to make the call about whether to go ahead with fetal surgery, which can be very risky. Since the procedure was such a success, the new mum wants to spread the word. She said: We want people to know a termination is not their only option because weaposve spoken to people and some didnapost even know it was an option. When youaposre given a diagnosis like this, you donapost know what to do. With us sharing Prestonaposs story we hope people will read it and feel hope. If we can help just one person who is going through the same thing who is maybe not sure what to do or whether they should have a termination then that would be amazing. They say itaposs a snowflake condition- it affects every child dferently so no one knows what is going to happen. Deborah added: Heaposs our little superhero, we couldnapost be prouder. Heaposs shown us what true bravery, courage, and determination is. Most people never meet their hero but we are raising ours. Heaposs such an inspiration. title: woman blew kisses after glassing
story: Woman blew kisses after glassing man while off her face on cocaine and boozeKatie Murphy, , "swilled" a drink at the stranger, Joseph Walker, and smashed the glass in his face during the sickening attack at Masquerade bar in LiverpoolKate Murphy blew kisses at a man she glassed on a night out Image: Liverpool EchoByAlan Weston:,  Oct | commentsA woman glassed a stranger and then blew kisses at him while off her face on cocaine and booze, a court heard. Katie Murphy, , attacked the man, Joseph Walker, as he was out for drinks with friends at the busy Masquerade bar in Liverpool.The glass narrowly missed Mr Walkeraposs right eye but he was left with signicant injuries which will leave him permanently scarred, the Liverpool Echo reported.Murphy of Stonyfield, Netherton, previously admitted she was off her face after a cocaine and alcohol binge which started the night before the attack on the evening of October  last year. She appeared at Liverpool Crown Court for sentencing on Friday after pleading guilty to causing grievous bodily harm without intent.  CCTV showed Mr Walker chatting and drinking with friends at the bar in the moments leading up to the sickening attack. Suddenly, while Mr Walker is looking down at his phone, he is approached by Murphy, who swilled a drink at him and smashed the glass in his face. She then blew two kisses at the victim before walking outside. Chris Hopkins, prosecuting, said: Mr Walker described a hand appearing with a glass which was thrust into his face. The glass broke with the impact. He bled profusely and was left with a jagged wound. He was taken to hospital and needed four internal stitches and  external stitches above his right eye. In his victim statement, Mr Walker said he now has a visible scar to his forehead, and he had become conscious of the way he looked. He added: I had a bubbly, happy nature before this happened, but I am now more nervous around people. I still donapost know why it was me she did it to. Maybe it was mistaken identity, maybe she just didnapost like the look of me. The injury was very close to my eye and it could have been a lot worse. Mr Walker bravely said he had forgiven his attacker. Mike Hagerty, defending, said Murphy accepted the victim of her attack was wholly innocent. He added: The defendant has a signicant mental health problem, including a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia, which is exacerbated by the use of drugs and alcohol. She has expressed regret and is remorseful. Judge Recorder Richard Leiper QC sentenced Murphy to  weeks in prison, suspended for  months. She was ordered to undergo a mental health and a drug rehabilitation programme, along with  hours of unpaid work. title: womans terrifying ordeal after hotel
story: Exclusive: Womans terrying ordeal after hotel gave sex pest a key to her roomA terried student, , says a hotel receptionist gave an alleged sex pest a key to her room before he allegedly harassed and robbed her, leaving her shaking in fearDorset City Hotel, LondonByAmy SharpeSunday Mirror reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct An alleged sex pest got into a young woman’s room at a luxury hotel after tricking a receptionist into handing him her key. The terried student, , claimed the man first tried to chat her up in the hotel’s rooftop bar. She rejected his advances so he told staff he was her partner to get a room key at London’s Dorsett City Hotel. The woman said he sexually harassed and robbed her ­before fleeing. She said: “I was terried when I realised he was in my room. “I’m so angry at the hotel for putting me at risk. “Even though there’s a phone in the room the receptionist didn’t check with me. They didn’t ask for ID.” Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newslettersThe victim said the man first spoke to her in the hotel’s Skybar. She claimed: “I made an excuse to leave but he followed me in the lt to my room, which freaked me out. This must have been , maybe am. I told him he couldn’t come in and went to bed, thinking that’d be the end of it.” Ten minutes later he got in her room. She said. “I suffer with panic disorder and was shaking so badly thinking I’m alone and this guy is in the room. “I didn’t know what to do so I gave him a glass of water, then sat on my bed and secretly messaged a male friend. Then the man came and sat next to me in the bed and lay down on my legs. “When I asked him to leave he said he’d hit me and didn’t care that I was a girl.” She said he then made a crude remark, adding: “I was really scared.”  The student was only able to get him out when she called her friend and put him on loudspeaker. “He said he was literally round the corner,” she explained. “So this guy called his cousin who came and picked him up.” She “ran to the reception crying” and told staff, who gave her a bottle of water and a dferent room. The woman claimed: “The next morning I realised he had taken my bag containing a £ train ticket home, my bank cards, iPod and passport.” It was only after she contacted police that she learned a receptionist had granted him access. The woman claimed the hotel gave no apology, refund or compensation besides a free breakfast and Tube fare. She added: “When I go to sleep I still sometimes feel like someone will come into the room. I was vulnerable – I wasn’t sober or in a good place – and anything could have happened.” City of London Police have released CCTV footage of a man leaving the four-star hotel on September . Det Insp Hannah Sydney said: “This was an awful incident which we are thoroughly investigating. If anyone saw this man, please get in touch.” The hotel was asked for comment. story: Zumba-mad woman becomes UKs first qualied instructor with Downs syndromeHannah Payton, from Atherton, near Wigan, in Greater Manchester, has become the UKs first qualied Zumba instructor with Downs syndrome - having become hooked during lockdownHannah Payton has become the first Zumba instructor with Downs syndrome in the UK Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByHollie Bone:,  Oct | commentsZumba fan Hannah Payton has become the UK’s first qualied instructor with Down’s syndrome. Hannah got hooked on the Latin aerobics routines during lockdown when she had to shield due to her condition. And when she finally met instructor Emma Golpys once gyms reopened, she became determined to qualy as a teacher herself. Hannah, , said: “I had a dream to be a Zumba instructor and it’s come true. “I could not be happier, I’m really proud. My family and friends are over the moon for me too, especially my sister Nicola.” Hannah is even determined to get her -month-old niece involved, adding: “I hope she’ll come along for some baby Zumba.”  Based around four Latin rhythms, Zumba was created  years ago after aerobics instructor Alberto Perez forgot his usual music and put on a salsa tape instead. Hannah, from Atherton, Gtr Manchester, said: “I want to prove it’s for everyone. “You can stay active and fit, surrounded by other people who just love to dance.” Hannah signed up after lockdown put an end to her swimming and badminton. title: woman claims mugged after google
story: Woman claims she was mugged after Google Maps sent her along most dangerous city roadThe notorious road highlighted on Google Maps was in the El Vacie neighbourhood in Seville, Spain. Police told the woman it was one of the most dangerous parts of the cityThe route took her through the El Vacie area Image: Google MapsByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Oct | comments A woman has claimed she was beaten and kicked in the head for her purse, after following a Google Maps route through one of Spain aposs most dangerous roads. The notorious road was in the El Vacie neighbourhood, which had been earmarked to be demolished in , but had been delayed due to the pandemic. The woman said she had only just moved to Spain and was walking back from a supermarket to her rental AirBnB.As she was new to the area and to stop herself from getting lost she decided to map her route on the popular Google app, which chooses the quickest or most direct route for users.Speaking on Reddit about what she describes as an horric incident she claimed she was brutally mugged moments after entering the dodgy neighbourhood.Has Google Maps ever sent you on a risky route  Let us know in the comments  She wrote: So I moved to Sevilla in Spain this week, and I was walking back to my Airbnb from the supermarket. Because it was my first day there I used google maps for the route back. She said she turned a corner on to an empty road. Before I could decide to turn around, a man ran up to me and grabbed my purse. When I didn’t let go he kicked my head in until I gave up. I spent the rest of the day in the hospital. All the police and hospital staff asked me what the hell I was doing there, because itaposs the most dangerous neighbourhood of Seville.  When I went to the police station the next day to make a report, I was again told by three officers how I should never go even near that street, because it was so dangerous. All I could respond with was that Google Maps lead me through there.In , the mayor of Seville announced that El Vacie would be dismantled and its residents relocated with the help of European Union funding.The work has been postponed due to the pandemic, no date has been set for the relocation and demolition works. title: see inside aberdeens under the hammer ahead of its opening next week
story: One of Aberdeen’s beloved pubs, which closed in March last year, will reopen under new ownership next week following an extensive refurbishment. Under the Hammer has been taken over by independent hospitality operators, The McGinty’s Group, and will open on Friday November  at pm. The popular basement bar located on North Silver Street, just off Golden Square, will reopen with a stylish new look with a new hand-crafted bar and modern interiors with a nod to the venue’s heritage throughout.

title: its going to be transformational what changes are coming to buckie harbour from moray west offshore wind farm
story: Confirmation that Buckie Harbour will become an operations and maintenance base for the Moray West offshore wind farm will lead to huge changes at the port. The existing harbour office will be demolished to make way for a new building that will manage the turbines as well as their construction and upkeep. The new command centre is just one of several massive changes due at Buckie Harbour following the Moray West announcement.

title: angus macneil i certainly would not bet on the scottish government managing to hold a referendum
story: Events in politics may now mean for certain that a referendum on Scottish independence is blocked and the only avenue to ask the population the question on independence is at an election, says SNP MP for the Western Isles, Angus MacNeil. This month’s Supreme Court decision on blocking Scottish Parliament bills was a seismic event which could affect the independence process for Scotland for years to come.
