infrastructure.Transport is a devolved matter, however Scotland will get money through the Barnett formula, which is what the UK government uses when they spend more money in England to keep spending more fair.Although Scotland will get money because England are spending more on transport, the Scottish government can do what they please with this money and do not necessarily need to use it for transport.Health is completely devolved, so announcements regarding funding for the NHS refer to NHS England only.However, Scotland will once again get money through the Barnett system, which they could choose to spend on the NHS.For example, during yesterdays Covid update, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the Scottish government would spend additional money on NHS Scotland.Fuel duty is a tax included in the price ofpetrol, diesel and other fuels used in vehicles or for heating.It is reserved to Westminster, meaning the freeze to the price of fuel duty will apply to Scotland.Foreign affairs are not devolved, so the UK government is in charge of Great Britains border control.This means that thepoundm to protect UK borders, including poundm for a new fleet of patrol boats, will apply to Scotland.According to the UK government, this fund aims to invest in infrastructures which will improve every day le for people across the UK.This pound million allocated to Scotland will back projects in places including Aberdeen and Lewis, Rishi Sunak said in todays announcement.Through the Barnett formula, there will be an increase to Scottish Governmentfunding in each year by pound. billion, according to the chancellor.Yes, alcohol duty is reserved to Westminster, so the announcement that alcohol dutywill increase on stronger alcohols such as fortied wine and higher volume red wines will apply to Scotland.A new lower rate of alcohol duty on draught beers and cider will also apply to Scotland, as willthe cancellation of theplanned increase in duty on spirits like Scotch Whisky, wine, cider and beer - which will come into action from midnight tonight.

title: latest-coronavirus-statistics-east-lothian
story: Between October and October , cases of Covid- were recorded in East Lothian, giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..A week earlier, between October and October , cases were recorded, a seven-day positive rate of ..The last Covid-related death recorded in East Lothian was on October , bringing the total number to .The current coronavirus hotspot in East Lothian is North Berwick South, where cases have been recorded in the last seven days, giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of .. The vast majority of areas of the county have seven-day positive rates per , people between  and .With regards to vaccinations, , residents over the age of  have received a second dose of a coronavirus vaccine, or . per cent, while , have received their first dose.

title: johnnie-meechans-miracle-recovery-nearly-dying-covid-19
story: Johnnie Meechan, a -year-old fundraising father-of-five, was diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumour, commonly known as NET, in .Since his diagnosis, Johnnie has blogged about his battle with cancer and his ongoing fundraising efforts on his lsquoJohnniersquos Journeyrsquo social media pages.He told the Courier of his horric ordeal with Covid after spending a ldquohorrendous eight days in hospital last month ndash and urged people to take the virus seriously and get vaccinated.Johnnie, who is double-vaccinated, said: ldquoAt the beginning of September, I tested positive for Covid after my family had the virus one by one.ldquoIt started with my eldest son and I was the last to get it, which was surprising because I have a weak immune system, but it gave me the opportunity to look after my family first.ldquoI was OK for a few days until I went to bed one night and my we couldnrsquot wake me the next morning.ldquoAn ambulance was called as I slipped in and out of consciousness.Johnnie was rushed to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and upon arrival was informed by two doctors that his organs were failing.He was delivered the devastating news that he would ldquonot live to see the next day.He said: ldquoThe night I arrived, the doctor said to me every organ was failing.ldquoI wouldnrsquot see the next morning andI did it would be a miracle.Johnnie also claimed that he did not have a choice about not being assigned resuscitation.ldquoMy family were distraught and were firmly under the impression I was going to die that evening, he added.ldquoI wasnrsquot able to speak to my we during that time as I could hardly breathe for the first few days.ldquoYou donrsquot just go in and tell someone: lsquoLook, yoursquore dead so it doesnrsquot matter what we do, you donrsquot have a hope in hell.rsquo I just donrsquot accept that my imprint, my le, my story does not go around that mould. I never accepted it, I pushed through.Johnnie praised the hard work of medical staff in the hospital who he said were ldquoworking against a wave that they have no way of stopping.He added: ldquoIt feels like they are patching wounds that continue to bleed.ldquoItrsquos like a bed and breakfast, except most donrsquot come out.Johnnie was hit with another devastating blow once he left hospital.While reading over his discharge letter, Johnnie discovered that he had battled severe sepsis during his stay.Due to his treatment, Johnniersquos pancreas was ldquopumped full of steroids and he left hospital needing to inject himself with insulin twice a day.ldquoI went in mildly diabetic needing only one tablet a day, he said. ldquoNow, I have to inject insulin twice a day and I check my blood five times a day.Johnniersquos friend William Turner recently cycled Mont Ventoux in France and raised pound, for Johnniersquos Journey.He said: ldquoGiven Johnniersquos weakened immune system, it was a worry for all of us when Covid got into the house and spread through the family.ldquoIt sounds like Johnnie had to fight back from the brink to beat it and we are all very relieved he did.ldquoHis experience on the Covid ward sounded horrendous and mirrored a lot of what my dad had told me when he was in last year.ldquoIrsquom glad he was able to find that extra push to get through it and home again in the circumstances.ldquoJohnnie often talks of his thoughts that any illness is potentially his last so it always creates massive worry.ldquoThe NHS staff deserve praise for their work in constant dficult circumstances and with limited resources.Johnnie added: ldquoIrsquove got a young family and my time might come sooner than most, but I am not going out like that, no way.ldquoI was fighting to get home to my family to see them again, to bring a message to people, one Irsquove preached myself many times that Covid is real.ldquoPeople will sit and argue that theyrsquove read this and that, but they donrsquot know nothing.ldquoWhen yoursquore sitting in a hospital room sucking on a ventilator waiting to die, then you can tell me I donrsquot want your ventilator, I donrsquot want your vaccines. Then yoursquoll know.Johnnie has since urged his followers to get vaccinated and understand that the virus is real.He added: ldquoItrsquos heartbreaking up there, we sit oblivious for the most part unless directly affected.ldquoIf I wasnrsquot double vaccinated I wouldnrsquot be here, itrsquos that simple.ldquoPlease get vaccinated. Itrsquos not just about your own beliefs, you are risking thousands of lives.ldquoWhen it does come knocking, and it will, Irsquod bet my left leg yoursquod sell your soul for the protection and ventilators required to live.ldquoLe gets ripped out your hands without an ounce of warning ndash it can and will happen to anyone.ldquoChoose le whilst itrsquos there.Dr Tracey Gillies, medical director, NHS Lothian, said: ldquoBeing admitted to hospital at any time can be a distressing and disorientating time for any patient, especiallythey are very unwell."If Mr Meechan has any concerns or questions, he should contact us directly to discuss further.

title: claim-self-catering-now-lifestyle-holiday-choice-bid-made-flat-used-holiday-let
story: The growing popularity of Airbnb properties and domestic holidays are being used to argue the case for a three-bedroom property in the village to be used as a holiday let.Felicity Rabbitte has applied to East Lothian Council for a retrospective change of use for the flat in Marine House, on Muirfield Drive and she has pointed to recent surveys of tourists to make her case.Referring to an Airbnb study which estimated its listings alone generated .million visitors in , averaging  visitors a year for every short-term let, she said that, while her property did not use the Airbnb , the evidence showed a change in attitude to self-catering. She said: ldquoSelf-catering is not a budget thing now, itrsquos much more about a lestyle trip ndash people want their own private space and clients want to be able to work in their flats.ldquoPeople are now more particular. Itrsquos about lestyle, cooking, and private and flexible space.And in her statement applying for the change of use for the flat, she said that a survey commissioned by East Lothian Council had revealed that half of all overnight visitors to the county stayed in caravan parks or rented flats or houses.She said that recent surveys of visitors to East Lothian highlighted the need for more flexible accommodation to encourage them to stay.She said: ldquoItrsquos about the tourism industry ndash driving and growing it, people spending money in the economy.ldquoHotels cannot support the volume of people visiting the area. There has to be more accommodationtourism is going to continue to grow and itrsquos great for the local economy.The application for change of use is being considered by officers and is available to view on the councilrsquos planning portal.

title: east-lintons-phone-box-covered-climate-emergency-messages-weekly-vigils-planned
story: Climate Action East Lintonhas renovated the phone box, on East Lintonrsquos High Street, ahead of the COP climate change conference in Glasgow.Members of the community and primary school were invited to write messages, which can now be viewed in the windows of the phone box, in time for COPrsquos launch on Sunday.To promote the initiative, CAEL members also dressed in clothing from the s ndash when the phone box was erected ndash to the s, when mobile phones came into use.CAEL members are meeting East Lothianrsquos MSP Paul McLennan on Saturday at am.A spokesperson for the group, whose vision is for the East Linton area to become ldquoa carbon-neutral, resilient community in balance with nature, said: ldquoAt a time where so many feel powerless and unable to have our voices heard, this is a way in which community voices can come together and share their depth of feeling.ldquoKey messages will be taken to Glasgow on banners and subsequently sent to politicians.Additional activities are planned, including weekly vigils in The Square. The vigils, which take place -pm this Saturday and also on November  and , are for quiet contemplation and the chance for people to come together. There will also be a community presence at the phone box from am to pm tomorrow , Saturday and Sunday.

title: bells-silenced-much-day-knox-academy
story: Pupils and staff at the secondary school will start November with a reduced number of school bells.The decision was taken following a consultation in the school.Benefits of a lsquono bells minimal bellsrsquo policy was said to include better time management and reduction in anxiety for youngsters with additional support needs.Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, confirmed that the month-long trial would start on Monday.She said: ldquoFollowing this month, we will carry out an evaluation to seewe retain this.ldquoDuring this time, we will only have a bell to mark the start of the school day, the end of break, lunch and end of the day.ldquoTimekeeping by staff and pupils will be paramount to making this successful and is a great le skill to have.

title: haddington-farmers-market-stallholder-thanks-public-money-help-save-cows
story: A combination of loss of income due to the global pandemic and a run of wet weather left Brenda Leddy, of Stichill Jerseys, Kelso, unable to meet the costs of repairing her cowshed.The -year-old decided to launch a fundraiser.She said: ldquoI was totally overwhelmed by peoplersquos generosity and especially in Haddington.ldquoI have been selling my Jersey cream, butter, clotted cream, cheese and dairy desserts at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market for about  years now and I have got to know so many people who have become loyal customers over that time.Brendarsquos cows are the only herd of their kind in the Borders.She will be back at the farmersrsquo market, on Court Street, this Saturday.The market, which runs from am to pm, has been a staple of the social calendar for more than  years and regularly attracts hundreds of visitors.Brenda added: ldquoDuring Covid, things were very tough financially.ldquoFarmersrsquo markets are my main source of income and they were all closed for months during the pandemic.ldquoHowever, like most farmers, my costs still continued ndash feed, vet bills, overheads, etc.ldquoWhen the cowshed needed repairing, it was the last straw.ldquoPerhaps foolishly, I decided to soldier on and try and save the Jersey cows.ldquoThrough the East Lothian Courier, I just wanted to say a big thank you to all those who have supported me.ldquoFor example, a customer handed me an envelope at the farmersrsquo market which I didnrsquot open until I got home. I just sat down and wept at the sheer generosity of this gt.To visit the fundraising page, go to gofundme f save-our-boarder-jersey-cows

title: dunbear-sculpture-lit-green-ahead-start-cop26
story: The five-metre-high steel sculpture of a brown bear was designed by Andy Scott, who also designed The Kelpies, and was unveiled in  as the focal point for the area to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store.The sculpture is a tribute to John Muir, the Dunbar-born naturalist and conservationist who emigrated to the USA. He travelled extensively in the country, helping to form the Sierra Club which has gone on to be one of the largest environmental organisations in the world.Now, the sculpture will turn green ahead of the conference, which starts on Monday.Ken Ross, from Hallhill Developments Limited, which has plans to transform the area into a low-carbon mixed-use development, said: ldquoBeing in such a prominent position at the gateway to Dunbar, the stunning DunBear sculpture provides the perfect opportunity to commemorate key events such as COP, one of the most important global meetings ever to take place in the UK.ldquoIt is also fitting that it should be part of our low-carbon community of DunBear Park, which through signicant investment will adopt the latest low-carbon technology, with renewable heat and power generated onsite, delivering on our ambitious goal to be an exemplar low-carbon development.ldquoThe DunBear not only celebrates the work of one man but also reminds us we can each make a positive contribution to climate change and reduce global warming for future generations.

title: msp-welcomes-pilgrims-journey-cop26
story: Paul McLennan welcomed those walking from northern Europe as they passed through North Berwick at the end of last week.The politician described it as ldquohumbling to meet people making the trek in what he said was ldquoour last chance to fix the climate emergency.Mr McLennan also mentioned his visits to Germany and said: ldquoIrsquove supported Scottish football teams and often it doesnrsquot end well but, in spite of that, I love Germany, I love Europe, and my heart broke when the UK voted for Brexit.He added: ldquoI hope that we find a way back into Europe because Irsquom Scottish but Irsquom also European.One of the leading organisers of the pilgrimage, German IT specialist Jens Knoumllker, assured Mr McLennan that ldquothe door is wide open for Scotland.A veteran of numerous pilgrimages dating back to , Mr Knoumllker said: ldquoThis pilgrimage has been dferent.ldquoIn , we found people wanted to engage but sometimes they were hostile because their lives had already been impacted by the green agenda.ldquoIn , we are speaking to so many people who tell us: lsquoYou are right you are heroes.rsquo Thatrsquos a big change among people, and wersquore also getting more media coverage.ldquoEven when we passed by Torness, the police, while doing their duty to ensure the security of the nuclear plant, wished us well and told us our ideas were right.The pilgrimsrsquo day ended with a barbecue organised by supporters of the recently inaugurated lsquoForth to Farnersquo pilgrimage route.This pathway from North Berwick to Lindisfarne revives a medieval tradition.North Berwick parish priest Father Augustine Bobi accommodated the group at Our Lady Star of the Sea, blessing what lay ahead on the pilgrimsrsquo journey and praying for a positive COP outcome.

title: beach-demonstration-north-berwick-gather-residents-thoughts-climate-change
story: Sustaining North Berwick, led by local mums Kathy Duncan, Fiona Fleming and Ruth Hunter-Pepper, has organised a beach demonstration for Sunday, the launch day of the global conference in Glasgow.The demo will be on North Berwickrsquos West Beach, at the foot of Elcho Green, and will feature a short talk by Dr Eurig Scandrett, former head of community action at Friends of the Earth Scotland.Everyone is invited to join, at -pm, with placards and banners.

title: youngsters-chosen-chorus-bruntons-2021-pantomime
story: The new production for the Musselburgh-based theatre has been created by award-winning writer and theatre maker John Binnie, who wrote past pantos Jack and the Beanstalk and Cinderella, which were well received by audiences.In , amidst the Covid- pandemic, he also wrote and directed Rapunzel, which was enjoyed by many schools and families who viewed it online during the festive period.Auditions took place last month to recruit  young performers from East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh for the panto.They will work alongside a few familiar faces ndash Eilidh Weir, who plays the role of Gretel, and Ross Donnachie as her wee brother Hansel.Experienced panto dame Graham Crammond s in the role of Dame Maisie Nature, with panto baddy Wendy Seager as Witch Wart-Nose.The chorus is made up of: Group  ndash Maggie Boyd, Robyn Devine, Eve Fairbairn, Jenny Hansen, Lily Paxton and Kharim Mather Group  ndash Halle Walls, Rachel Bennie, Roma Millar, Marianna McCartney, Keira McCartney, Emily Bain, Lexie Blance and Martha Stitt Group  ndash Kristin Boby, Faith Dowie, Ziara Franklin, Willow Fraser, Rose Grant, Erin Benson McGinley, Pippa McNeill and Niamh Maya Ritchie Group  ndash Amy Clark, Rebecca Davis, Caileigh Greig, Ailsa McKinnie, Caitlin Quinn and Isla Ridley and Group  ndash Carrie Steedman, Isla McEwan, Tegan Taylor, Abbie Lumsden, Hope Harvey and Ella Davies.The Hansel and Gretel creative team includes set and costume designer Robin Mitchell, musical director Tommie Travers, and Amy Robinson as choreographer.The show, which has been described as ldquoa festive production and a treat full of fun and laughter with oodles of gags, local references, chart hits, outrageous costumes and shouting out, will run from December  to .Tickets are available from The Brunton on    or thebrunton

title: clocks-go-back-weekend---time
story: Between Saturday night and Sunday morning, we will gain an extra hour,meaning it will be lighter in the mornings but darker in the evenings.Clocks changes always take place on the weekend to try and limit disruption to everday le.Heres what you need to know about when the clocks will change, what time and why they go back...The clocks will go back in the early hours ofSunday October .They go back on the same weekend every year, with the change always taking place on the last Sunday of October.: Does my iPhone automatically update the time The change to the clocks will comeinto effect around am on Sunday.It means we are reverting back to GMT, which stands for Greenwich Mean Time and is thestandard time against which time zones in other areas of theworldare measured.Meanwhile, BST stands for British Summer Time and is the time zone referenced when the clocks go forward in spring.The BSTis GMT+ hour.The principal reason we change the clocks is to get the most out of the daylight.The first clock change was introduced by the German government in  during the first world war as a means of saving energy - the longer the daylight hours lasted, the less electricity required.Yes! The good news about the clocks going back is we get an extra hour inthe day - or an extra hour to sleep!The clocks might only just be going back, but you may already be wondering when they will go forward again...We have a wee while to wait, with the next clock change scheduled for March , when they will go forwardin order to make the most of the long hours of daylight.Like in autumn, the change will take place on a Sunday to avoid too much disruption.Next years change will take place on Sunday March  , marking the start of BST.The clocks going forward means we lose an hour, however we gain this back every autumn when they go back again.

title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good news is that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .During this day, the northern hemisphere will only see around hours  minutes of daylight.The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travel the darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: scottish-fish-shops-need-visit-britains-best-revealed
story: There is nothing quite like a fish supper, and the National Federation of Fish Fryers yearly guide to quality fish and chips is here to help you seek out the finest across the UK.Named in the guide are Scottish chippies, includingBritains most northerly fish and chip shop.With the weekend just around the corner, here are Scotlands best fish and chip shops as according to the National Federation of Fish Friers...Frankies Fish and ChipsBrae, ShetlandLocated in Shetland, Frankies Fish and Chips boasts the title of the UKs most northerly chippy. With sea views over Busta voe, you can enjoy fish, chips, seafood, homemade cakes, teas and coffees.Moores Fish and Chip Shop King Street, Castle Douglas, DumfriesMoores serves traditional Scottish fish and chips as well as pies, burgers, kebabs and ice cream.Lows Traditional Fish and ChipsUnit , Westhill Shopping Centre, WesthillUnite  , Berryden Business Park, AberdeenSo good it has two branches on the list! This -year old award winning family company serves fresh food and offers vegan and coliec options.Scrabster Seafood BarThe Harbour, Scrabster, Caithness, HighlandThis fish and chip shop works with local fisherman in Scrabster to sell seasonal and sustainable fish, shellfood and seafood.Sea Salt and SoleStation Road, Dyce, AberdeenThis family owned fish shop takes pride in selling locally sourced produce.The Eating Plaice High Street, Alness, Ross-shireLocated in Alness, The Eating Plaice is "committedto providing the best food and drink experience in your own home".The Fish Hoose Main Street, Thornton, FeAll produce from the multi award winning Fish Hoose is sourced sustainably.The House of BruarBy Blair Atholl, Pitlochry, PerthshireThe House of Bruaris a famous Scottish institution, and now it has added fish and chips to its ranks.The AshvaleNumerous venues across AberdeenshireWith over -years of award winning experience, the Ashvale certainly knows what its doing when it comes to fish and chips.The Fish Works The Promenade, Largs, North AyrshireAnother family run business, husband and we duo Ross and Tfany have over -years experience in the industry, with their chippy offering great views of Firth of Clyde.The Real Food CafeTyndrum, PerthshireThis roadside diner is the perfect stop off for not only fish and chips, but also breakfast, lunch, dinner, homebaking, tea and coffee.The Waterfront ChipShop Shore Street, Anstruther, FeA traditional fish shop that uses their very own family recipe to batter the fresh fish and assures "you wont be disappointed".The Wee Chippy Shore Street, Anstruther, FeAnstruther is famous for its fish and chips: just down the road from the The Waterfront Chip Shop is The Wee Chippy, where you can purchase freshly fried fish to order from the family business.

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-today-time-watch-live
story: It comes just days after the first ministers latest update to Scottish Parliament, where she expressed slight concern over the number of hospitalisations in Scotland.With COP due to begin on Sunday in Glasgow, there have been warnings that Scotland could see a sharp rise in cases following the climate conference.On Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said she could not rule out introducing further restrictions in the futurerequired to curb case rates.The first minister and national clinical director will be joined byPolice Scotland Chief Constable Iain Livingstone to discuss COP, which will take place from October  - November .Heres everything you need to know about the briefing, including what time and how to watch live...The first minister will host a media briefing at pm today alongside Jason Leitch and Iain Livingstone from Police Scotland.It will take place fromAtlantic Quay in Glasgow, with journalists asking questions both in person and via Zoom.The media briefing is expected to be streamed on the Scottish Governments social media s including Twitter and Facebook.It is also expected to be available to watch on the Scottish Government website.During Tuesdays briefing, Nicola Sturgeon warned that Covid hospitalisations had seen a slight rise, with infection now more prevalent in the older population.This is depsite Covid rates in Scotland being lower than England, Wales and Northern Ireland, as confirmed by the first minister during her statement.She also confirmed that from Sunday, fully vaccinated people travelling to Scotland from abroad would only be required to provide a lateral flow test within -hours of arrival, instead of a PCR test.Lateral flow test are around pound- cheaper than PCR tests, and this guidance is inkeeping with the UK government guidelines on international travel.

title: scotland-rugby-channel-watch-scotland-v-tonga-weekend-autumn-series
story: As October draws to a close, the rugby season is well and truly underway, with the match between the teams their first head to head since .It was Scotland who proved triumphant at their last encounter, scoring five tries to beat Tonga - at Kilmarnock.The odds on paper are tipped in Scotlands favour: of the four meetings with Tonga, Scotland have won three.In front of a home crowd at Murrayfield, the team will look to extend this track record to four wins, as the autumn international series gets underway.Heres what you need to know about Saturdays Scotland match against Tonga...The Scotland v Tonga match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday October at :pm.It marks the start of the autumn international series, which will last throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmScotland TeamForwards Pierre Schoeman George Turner Zander Fagerson Jamie Hodgson Rob Harley Jamie Ritchie  Hamish Watson Matt FagersonBacks Ali Price  Blair Kinghorn Rufus McLean Sam Johnson Sione Tuipulotu Kyle Steyn Darcy GrahamReplacements Stuart McInally Jamie Bhatti Oli Kebble Marshall Sykes Luke Crosbie Nick Haining Jamie Dobie Ross Thompson

title: covid-nicola-sturgeon-say-cop26-update-today
story: During Tuesdays Covid update to Parliament, the first minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising, with more cases among the older population.Amid warnings that case numbers could surgefollowing the climate conference, which will see over tens of thousands of people flock to the city, today the first minister outlined how the government aimed to protect both citizens and those visiting.Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged that the summit would bring a certain level of disruption, due to the extremely high profile nature of the event.Heres what we learned from the update today...The first minister encourgaged people to avoid travelling across Glasgow and the central belt where possible, particularly in the first few days of COP.She said that this did not only apply to road travel, but also by rail, following the news that ScotRail workers will no longer be striking during the conference.If travel is necessary, the government advise planning journeys carefully.According to the first minister, the first Sunday, Monday and Tuesday of COP will be particularly busy as world leaders come together.Next Friday and Saturday will see large scale protests across the city, with Saturdays event expected to see up to , people march from Kelvingrove Park to Glasgow Green.Scottish government doing everything they can to mitigate the spread of Covid, according to the first minister.Explainging that she understood why people may be wary, Nicola Sturgeon said that the government was working with the UN to try and minimise a surge in Covid followingthe conference.The first minister acknowledged the disruption to the people of Glasgow, and thanked residents for their patience.She added that the disruption was "for a purpose" with COP focussed on minimising global warming and climate change in the future.Police chiefIain Livingstone acknoweldged that the UN was encourgaing people to make their voices heard during the conference, and endorsed this message.However, he addedthat swt action would be taken against those intent on actually disrupting the Covid conference.Police Scotland said that physical interference would be required where protesters were preventing the conference from going ahead.Jason Leitch encouraged people to continue following the remaining Covidrules in Scotland, and urged people to be even more careful over the coming weeks.When asked how emergency services will cope with the added demand and the navigation of protests, Jason Leitch said there was a "many layered" approach.He added that Scotland was "ready" and the health service was "prepared" for COP.The first minister confirmed she would co-host an event on Tuesday afternoon with UK prime minister Boris Johnson.She also added that while the Scottish government and British government had some big dferences, they would work hard to come to the best outcome for the world over the coming days.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

title: gallery-modern-art-glasgow-closed-today-cop26
story: It is one of a number of Glasgow Le venues to close for the duration of the climate conference, which will see delegated and heads of state from around the world descend on the city.COP marks the biggest climate summit of the decade as countries come together to outline ambitious plans to combat global warming.Museums are not the only area of everyday le affectedbyCOP, with road closures, rail strikes and school closures also likely to cause disruptions.Heres what you need to know about the closure of the Gallery of Modern Art in Glasgow during COP...The Gallery of Modern Art is closed from pm on Saturday October , and will remain closed until am on MondayNovember .No access will be possible between Sunday October  and Sunday  November.They added: "This includes Gallery of Modern Art and wersquore sorry for any inconvenience this may cause."Riverside Museum:October -November Kelvingrove Museum: October  - November Kelvin Hall:October  -November Peoples Palace:Ongoing closure for "essential maintenance"A number of roads will close during COP which is expected to cause travel disruption in Glasgow.Congress Road - Closed October  to November : As expected the first road to close will be the one directly outside the SECC and Hydro, where the majority of talks will take place, and it will re-open at am on November .Congress Way: Partial closures with lane restrictions will begin on October  ad the full road closure will begin from pm on Sunday October . It will re-open November  in the morning.Clydeside Expressway ndash Partick Interchange to Anderston :The major dual carriageway will cause major disruption to commuters as the road is set to be closed from October , but it reopens earlier than others on November .Clyde Arc and Lancefield Quay: Road closed from October  to November Minerva Street ndash West Greenhill Place: Road Closed from October  to November .

title: cop26-glasgow-news-updates-free-herald

Our reporters, specialists, contributors andcolumnistsare ready to bring you expert analysis on all the big talking points over the two-week summit.From exclusive analysis to daily, breaking news, our award-winning teams will be all-hands-on-deck over the course of the summit as world leaders make their way to Glasgow.And you can access it all for free with our exclusive COP digital subscription trial.For two weeks, you can access all that The Herald has to offer for free.Head to our subscribe page and select the Premium option. This will entitle you to unlimited access to The Heralds digital  for two weeks.After that, itll be just pound. a month to continue this fantastic access after the conference.What will this free trial entitle you to during COP  We have a whole host of content for you over the next few weeks.Each day during COP, well be bringing you the latest in breaking news both inside and outside the conference. Well have reporters inside the SEC, and others on the streets of Glasgow ready to bring you the most up to date news from all across the city.Each day, well have experts from across the environmental sphere in our Voices Live section, promising analysis and opinion on the biggest issues of the day.And as a subscriber, you have access to our wide iety of newsletters - including our dedicated COP daily briefing. As the conference gets underway, our reporters will give registered users and subscribers a digest of whats to come throughout the day, and the biggest updates from the ground.A subscription will give you access to our unrivalled COP coverage as well as a number of unmissable perks.With that subscription, yoursquoll see % fewer adverts on our websiteand have unlimited access to all our stories, including premium articles.This means you will be able to readThe Heralds online coverage from our award-winning team uninterrupted.Itrsquos our job to make sure The Herald is your go-to site to keep you up-to-date.But as a Herald subscriber, you will also have access to exclusive "Premium" articles. Around one in five of our stories are onlyavailable to people who have signed up to a Herald subscription.These articles are the very best of what we do - written from ourtop writers across a range of specialisms, from politics, to sport, tobusiness, toarts. They could be analysis, comment, insight, interviews, features or big newsworthy investigations.This offer is valid until November , .After the initial free trial period, the subscription will be charged at pound. per month. All subscriptions will auto-renew unless cancelled. Please see newsquest digital-subscription-terms-and-conditions for full details.

title: glasgow-cathedral-opens-doors-world-cop26-neon-artwork-revealed
story: Glasgow Cathedral is a place with world-wide appeal while also being a local parish church and even during lockdown it kept its doors open, albeit virtually, with services beamed across the globe.Now with all eyes on Glasgow, as dozens of world leaders and thousands of delegates converge on the city for the critical COP UN world climate summit, the cathedral could find itself at the centre of messages of hope and reflection through a unique art installation.Read more: COP: Glasgows Lord Provost welcomes chance for history at summitIn what is believed to be a first for a Scottish cathedral, a public artwork with neon text is due to be unveiled this evening.The public will be able to have their first glimpse of Returning And Into Your Arms by Glasgow artist James Pfaff.It is described as a site-specic neon and sound installation which features a hand-drawn personal text from the artist and will be on show until January , .For Glasgow School of Art graduate Mr Pfaff the wording is particularly signicant as it reflects how he felt when he first ed to his home city in  after working in London and Hamburg and felt the city once again opened its arms to him.And it is hoped that it is a sentiment that people coming to Glasgow for COP will feel as the city plays hosts to them for the next two weeks.Both Mr Pfaff and Reverend Mark Johnstone, minister of Glasgow Cathedral, are delighted that the sign has been installed and ready to be viewed by the public.ldquoIrsquove been working on this neon installation with Glasgow Cathedral since , and Irsquom excited to have such a great stage at such an important moment to show the work, said Mr Pfaff.ldquoThe piece has multiple readings, but one message is clear - at this critical point in our climate emergency we mustto naturewe are to solve this crisis. It is, of course, for the viewer to react and find their own meaning within the work. I hope over the coming weeks the people of Glasgow can come and enjoy it, and enjoy the beautul building of which it has become a part of.ldquoI think I would like people to take their own meaning from it. For me it is about putting the work out there and when people see it for the first time perhaps it will take them a little bit by surprise."Read more: Glasgows Miles Better: Is it time to bring back citys most successful slogan While artists, including Tracey Emin, have installed artworks in cathedrals south of the border, itrsquos unheard in Scotland and puts the cathedral on the firmly on the map during a time when some of the cityrsquos tourists attractions such as the Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum and the Gallery of Modern Art have closed for the duration of COP. It could be argued that as one of the cityrsquos leading cultural religious location, that it is one of the few tourist attractions open during the summit.Rev Johnstone said: ldquoWe often respond to lsquosacred spacersquo emotionally, physically and spiritually. Some have said sacred space is founded on serious ground. When we encounter something unexpected in a space we thought could predict we can be startled. We may be more than startled when we encounter James Pfaffrsquos new neon piece within the cathedral. It brings the playful high street nuance of neon and places it in a context more associated with civic pomp. The new work allows the lsquolightrsquo to shine, proclaiming an embrace that can be seen as a spiritual mandate.Mr Johnstone described the installation at light across a dark cavernous space and that the eye is drawn towards as people make their way through the cathedral.The present building was consecrated in . Since that same period, the Cathedral has never been without a roof and worship has been carried out within its walls for more than  years.The Cathedral is the best-preserved example of a large church to have survived from the medieval period in Scotland and it has one of the finest post-war collections of stained-glass windows to be found in Britain.During the COP the cathedral is running a number of events including a vigil on Tuesday, November  led by the Iona Community. A special service will be held on Sunday, November  led by Lord Wallace, the Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, followed by a COP service.The installation reveal will be held at pm today and is open to the public.Also this evening award-winning artist collective Still Moving are bringing their  metre long and seven metre high light sculpture No New Worlds to Govan for COP.The sculpture has been installed on Govan Graving Docks with the support of a community crowdfunding campaign, with support from Clyde Docks Preservation Initiative. It will sit facing the main delegate zone for the duration of the conference - serving as a stark reminder to delegates that there is no such thing as a New World, we have no plan B. The location of No New Worlds will make it the backdrop to the conference, with both the giant puppet figures of Little Amal and STORM passing the sculpture.

title: exs9fq-jet2-plane-bound-glasgow-declares-squawk-7700
story: The Jet flight EXSFQ travelling from Palma De Mallorca inSpain to Glasgow International Airport, signalled the alert whilst travelling over the north of England.It has since landed, but the cause of the mid-air emergency is still to be confirmed.Live Squawk : Track EXSFQ live now with Plane Finder https:t.co aziFtFkZO #avgeek #EXSFQ pic nBNxGGsNVAn emergency squawk is used to identy an aircraft that has a possible issue and enables it to have priority over other air traffic.This is a breaking story, and both Jet and Glasgow International Airport have been contacted for comment.

title: kyle-steyn-wondered-ever-pull-scotland-jersey
story: The Glasgow Warriors winger made his Scotland debut in March , coming off the bench to help complete a memorable - win over France in the national teamrsquos last outing before lockdown called a halt for a time to all competitive sport. A y hamstring injury put paid to any hopes that Steyn might have had of adding to that solitary cap last season, then the cancellation of the planned summer Tests added further frustration.But he has been on impressive form in his early outings for Glasgow in this campaign, and showed the Murrayfield crowd - back for a Test for the first time since that France game - just how much they have been missing these past  months with a virtuoso display of finishing.Much of the talk in the build-up to the match had been about the eight debutants Gregor Townsend had selected in his matchday , and it was one of the octet, Rufus McLean, who seized the spotlight early on with his teamrsquos opening two tries. Then, however, Steyn took over where his Warriors team-mate left off, running in a hat-trick before half-time then adding a fourth after the break. It was the first time since Gavin Hastings in the  World Cup match against Ivory Coast that a Scotland player had touched down four times, and the first time altogether at Murrayfield, and Steyn, understandably, was a touch stunned by the whole experience.ldquoIrsquom absolutely buzzing - I canrsquot really put it into words, the -year-old said after the match. ldquoGregor said before the game that it had been  days since we had crowds in, and I was like, shit that means itrsquos  days since I last played for Scotland. Just the whole day, the whole atmosphere about it, was incredible.ldquoIrsquove had one hat-trick at uni level, but nothing like tonight. To be honest, you just get those days. Three of those tries were off set-piece plays where I get to e over in the corner, and then for the other one, Blair [Kinghorn] puts in a cross-kick - he made me work a little bit for it, I couldnrsquot get to it on the full.ldquoDays like this - you want them to come round for so long, then theyrsquore over in a flash. So Irsquove just been trying to soak it in and enjoy it with the boys in the changing room.When told he was the first Scot to score four tries in an international at Murrayfield, he added: ldquoThatrsquos incredibly special. Scottish rugby is steeped in so much history, so to have even a tiny part in that history is pretty humbling.It is not such a tiny part any longer, and, now that he has won a second cap at last, Steyn feels able to look back in good-humoured fashion about that frustrating year and a half which followed his first. ldquoAt one stage I thought someone didnrsquot want me to get a second cap. I was due to play Wales after France and that got canned the day before. Then we were lining up for the summer, with two opportunities there plus the A game, and we all know the story there.ldquoAt one stage, I was like lsquoSomeone has it in for all of us, maybe Irsquoll just stay on one and that will be me!rsquo.Steyn also had a word to say about McLean, who not only created his own tries out of next to nothing, but also began a counter-attack from deep inside his own half that eventually produced his fellow-wingerrsquos third score. ldquoWe keep saying you know what hersquos going to do, but because hersquos so fast, itrsquos so dficult to defend, he said of the -year-old. ldquoI thought all of the debutants were brilliant, which was awesome to see.

title: liam-kelly-scotland-hopes-learning-craig-gordon-move-motherwell
story: But Kelly made the major call to head back north to Motherwell on a permanent deal, and hersquos delighted itrsquos paid off as he hopes to earn another Scotland call-up this week.Steve Clarke is preparing to name his national side for the crucial World Cup qualiers against Moldova and Denmark with Kelly likely to be in the squad alongside Craig Gordon and Jon McLaughlin.But for Kelly, while it has been fruitful ing to Scotland, it was a decision purely based on game-time.ldquoI love playing football so that was the main reason I came back, explained Kelly.ldquoI could be a No in the English Championship with QPR right now but who is going to see me  I wouldnrsquot be involved in a game like the draw with St Mirren, my emotions wouldnrsquot be running high and I just think you should always play and yoursquoll find your level.ldquoIrsquove said so many times there are so many good goalkeepers in the country.ldquoIf I am selected then Irsquom so proud and so happy to be involved andother goalies get selected ahead of me then I just look at them and admire how good a goalie they are.ldquoIrsquom never too downbeatI donrsquot get in because the competition is so strong.ldquoIrsquom just trying to play well at Motherwell andthe manager at Scotland likes that then brilliant.Kelly knows Gordon is likely to take the No shirt but is thrilled to be in contention alongside the giant stopper after learning from him as a youngster.ldquoI was really fortunate that Craig Gordon was in at Rangers when I was there and he was doing his rehab", said Kelly."I was a youth team goalie and he did a lot of training with the under-s at the time to get himself back fit. So I had a lot of dealings with Craig then, that was back in .ldquoYou just need to try and push him as much as you can, make him play as well as he can play and ultimately that helps the country.ldquoI donrsquot ever remember him making a mistake, hersquos a brilliant goalie and I canrsquot speak highly enough of him.

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: community urged to pull together as covid cases rise by 55
story: coronavirusCommunity urged to #pull together# as COVID cases rise by October ,  at : pmAs Orkney records  new COVID- cases, the county#s public health team has urged the community to remain cautious around busy winter events.According to NHS Orkney, not all of the  cases attributed to Orkney today are from the past  hours — but there is a signicant level of community infection across the whole county.A backlog in reporting test results is partly behind the high number of cases reported this afternoon, but NHS Orkney#s interim chief executive has said he anticipates that figures will continue to rise in the coming days.Part of the issue, according to Michael Dickson and NHS Orkney director of public health Louise Wilson, is that many of the folk who are experiencing COVID- symptoms are continuing to go to work and attend events.#This virus is just so infectious,# Dr Wilson said in a press briefing this Thursday afternoon.#We really to be careful about what we are doing and how we are interacting.#We are seeing people who have symptoms who are still going out and about and continuing with their daily lives. We would urge these people to please isolate and get tested.#The community has been so good about this before, so we are really asking everyone to pull together again at this point.#The health authority has confirmed that the COVID Assessment Centre in Kirkwall will be open on both Saturday and Sunday, in addition to its usual hours, for testing.If you develop COVID- symptoms, or have a positive lateral flow test, you must self-isolate and seek a PCR test. You can book this by phoning  .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

story: The Scottish Government#s radical proposal of offering of up to £, to folk wishing to relocate to the isles has been branded a #gimmick# this week by Orkney MSP Liam McArthur.Mr McArthur#s suggestion that the Government should be investing in making island communities more resilient rather than #bribing iniduals# to relocate struck a nerve with cabinet secretary for rural affairs and islands, Mairi Gougeon, at Holyrood on Thursday.Ms Gougeon added: “This is one initiative that we hope will help tackle some of the problems that we see and we are determined and absolutely committed to listen to communities as we develop our proposals.”Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: #The Islands Bond promised by the government bears all the hallmarks of an election stunt.
